APPENDIX B MODULE SUMIAARY 326 RESOURCES 335 REVIEW QUESTIONS 326 Books 335 APPENDIX A Websites 335 LEGAL RESOURCES 327 GLOSSARY on Computer Fraud and Abuse Act of 1984 328 INDEX 353 Computer Fraud and Abuse Act of 1986 333 Copyages 2373 Camgage Leeming. 1.3 Migtts Raaaeved. try ect be copind, scammas of chgficated tn whole or fy part. ®TN-12-.200-206 Fd A Pe FS POT AP PONS A The need for security professionals who understand how attackers compromise networks ls grow: Ing each day. You can? read the news without seeing an article on ransomware or personal injormatlon being stolen trom unprotected databases. Since the first edition of Hands-On Ethical Hacking and Network Defense was published, the United States has created an organization with the sole
Purpose of countering cyber threats and attacks. Both public and private companies rely on skilled
professionals to conduct test altacks on their networks as a way to discover vulnerabilities before
attackers do. “Ethical hacker” is one term used to describe these professionals; others are “security
tester” or “penetration tester.”

This course isn’t intended to provide comprehensive tralning in security testing or penetration testing. It does, however, introduce security testing to those who are new to the field. This course Is intended for novices who have a thorough grounding in computer and networking basics but want to learn how to protect networks by using an attacker's knowledge to compromise network security. By understanding what tools and methods a hacker uses to break Into a network, security testers can protect systems irom these attacks.

The purpose of this course is to guide you toward becoming a skilled security tester. This profession requires creativity and critical thinking, which are sometimes difficult skills to learn in an academic environment. However, with an open mind and a willingness to learn, you can think outside the box and leam to ask more questions than this course or your Instructor poses. Being able to dig past the surface to solve a problem takes patience and the willingness to admit that somethnes there’s no simple answer.

Conducting a security test involves more than running exploits against a system and inform. Ing your client of existing vulnerabilities. Lsn’t 1t possible that you neglected to test for some areas thal might be vulnerable to attacks? Hapharard approaches undermine the security profession and expose companies to theft. The goal of this course is to offer a more structured approach to conducting a security test and to introduce novices to professional certliications available In this growing field.
INTENDED AUDIENCE

Although people with a wide range of backgrounds can take this course, It’s intended for those with a Security+ and Networks certification or equivalent. A networking background ls necessary so that you understand how compiners operate in a networked environment and can work with a network administrator when needed. In addition, readers must know how to use a computer from the conumand Ilne and bow to use popular operating systems, such as Windows and Kall Linux
This course can be used at any educational level, from technical high schools and community
colleges to graduate students. Current professionals in the public and private sectors can also use
this course.

CREATING A BOOTABLE USB FLASH DRIVE To install Kali Linux on a US8 Nash drive, you need a drive with a capacity of at least 8 GB. Note that the speed af some flash drives isn't adequate for running a live Linux OS. Performance improvements can be substantial if you use a flash drive with laster read and write speeds. WHAT YOU CAN DO LEGALLY Because laws involving computer technology change as rapidly as technology Itsel, you must keep abreast of what's happening In your area of the world. What's legal In Des Moines might not be legal in Indlanapolis, for example. Finding out what's legal In your state or country can be just as difitcult as performing penetration tests, however Many state officials aren't aware of the legallties surrounding computer technology. This conluslon also makes It <dlificult
10 prosecute wrongdoers in computer crimes. The average citizen on a jury doesn’t want to send a person to fall tor dolng something the state prosecutor hasn't clearly defined as illegal
AS a security tester, you must be aware of what you're allowed to do and what you should not or cannot do. For
example, some security testers know how to pick a deadbolt lock, so a locked door wouldn't deter them from gaining

physical access to a server. However, testers must be knowledgeable about the laws for possessing lockpicks before venturing out to a corporate site with tools In hand. In fact, laws vary Irom state to state and country to country. In some states, the mere possession of lockpicking tools constitures a crime, whereas other states allow possession as Jong as a crime hasn't been committed. In one state, you might be charged with a misdemeanor for possessing these tools; In another stare, you might be charged with a lelony.

Laws of the Land

As with lockpicking tools, having hacking took on your computer or mobile device might be legal You could contact Jocal law enforcement agencies or research online about the laws Jor your state or country betore installing hacking tools on your devices. You can see how complex this Issue gets as you travel trom state to state or country to country. New York City might have one law far installing hacking tools, and a quick drive over the George Washington Bridge beings you to a diiferent law in New Jersey. Table A-1, In Appendix A, compares Vermont's computer crime statutes to New York's to demonstrate the varlety of verbiage the legal community uses.

Laws are written to protect soclety, but often the written words are open to interpretation, which is why courts and Judges are necessary. In Hawaii, for example, the state must prove that the person charged with committing a crime on a computer had the “intent to commit a crime.” So just scanning a network isn’t a crime in Hawali Also, the state has the even more difficult task of having to prove that the computer used In committing a crime had been used by only one person—the one alleged to have committed the crime. If the person charged with the crime clalms that more than one person had access to the computer used to gather evidence of wrongdoing, the state can't use that computer as evidence.

What do these laws have to do with a network security professional using penetratlon-testing tools? Laws tor having hacking tools that allow you to view a company’s network infrastructure aren't as clearly defined as Laws tor Possession of lockpicking tools because laws haven't been able to keep up with the speed of technological advances. In some states, running a program that gives an attacker an overview and a detailed description of a company's network infrastructure Isn't seen as a threat.

As another example of how laws can vary, is taking photos of a bank’s exterbor and Interlor legal? Security personnel at a bank in Hawaii say you would be asked to stop taking photos and leave the premises. An FEI spokesperson put it
in simple terms: You can be asked to stop taking photos If you're on private property. Taking photos across the street
from the bank with a 200m lens Is legal, but 4 you use the photos to commit a crime in the finure, an attorney would
tell you the charges against you might be more serious. Because ol the fear of terrorism, in certain parts af the United
States and many parts of Europe, taking photos of bridges, train stations, and other public areas is Wegal.
The point oj mentioning all these laws and regulations is to make sure you're aware o/ the dangers of being a

security tester or a student learning hacking techniques. Is Port Scanning Legal? Port scanning is a common activity In penetration testing. Testers use port scanning to detect computing devices an a network and itemize the services they oiler. For example, if a scan detects that a computer af the [P address
192.168.1.100 has port 443 open for connections, the machine ls probably a web server and could later be targeted for web server penetration tests.

Same states consider part scanning as noninvasive or nondestructive in nature and deem It legal This isn’t always. the case, however, so you must be prudent before you start using penetration-testing tools. Some companies have filed criminal] charges against hackers tor scanning thelr systems, but judges ruled that no damage was dane to the networks, sa the charges were dismissed [t's just a matter of time before a business will claim that Its network Is also
private property, and It should have the right to say that scanning Is nat allowed.

Because the federal government currently doesn't see these Inbringements as a Vialation of the US. Constitution, each state is allowed ta address these issues separately. Each TCP flag occupies 1 bit of the TCP segment and can be set ta 0 (off) or 1 (on). These are the six flags of a TCP
segment:
© SYN flag—The synchronize flag signifies the beginning of a session.
© ACK flag—The acknowledgment Mag acknowledges a connection and Is sent by a host after receiving a SYN-
ACK packet.
© PSH flag—The push Mag is used to deliver data directly to an application Data Len’t bollered; it’s sent
immediately.
© URG flag—This Nag is used to signify urgent data
© RST fiog—The reset Mag resets or drops a connection.
© FIN flag—The finlsh flag signifies that the connectlan Is fintshed. Initial Sequence Number
The initial sequence number (iSN} is a 32-bit number that tracks packets received by a node and allows reassembling

Jarge packets that have been broken up into smaller packets. Steps 1 and 2 of the three-way handshake send an SSN. That Is, the [SN from the sending nade Is sent with the SYN packet, and the ISN from the receiving node Is sent back to
the sending node with the SYN-ACK packet. An ISN can be quite a large number because 2” allows a range af numbers fram zero ta more than four billion.

The most difficult part of a network security professionafs job Is balancing system security with ease of Lise and avallabiltty for users. Closing all ports and stopping all services would certainly make your network more secure, but your users couldn’ connect to the Intermet, send or receive email, or access any network resources. So your Job is to allow users to
work In a secure network environmen without preventing them from using services such as email and web browsing. This task isnt aasy, as youll learn throughout this course.

User Datagram Protocol {UDP) is a fast bot unrellable delivery protocol that operates on the Transport layer. Imagine

trying 10 compete in the mail courier business and touting that your service 1s fast but unreliable. It would probably be difficult to sell. However, UDP Is a widely used protocol on the Internet because of Its speed. It doesn’t need to verity whether the receiver Is listening or ready to accept the packets. The sender doesn’t care—it just sends, even if the receiver isn’t ready to accept the packet. See why it’s faster? Some applications that use UDP have builtin utilities to warn reciplents of undeliverable messages, but UDP doesn't. In other words, it depends on the higher layers of the TCP/IP stack to handle these problems. Think of UDP as someone announcing over a loudspeaker that school will be closed that alternoon. Some lucky students wil] hear the message, and some won't. This type of delivery protocol is reterred to as connectionless. The Internet Layer The Internet layer of the TCP/IP stack is responsible for routing a packet to a destination address. Routing is done by using a logical address, called an IP address. Like UDP, IP addressing packet delivery ls connectloniess. Internet Control Message Protocol
Internet Control Message Protaca! (ICMP) is used to send messages related to network operations. For exampk, if
a packet can’t reach its destination, you might see the “Destination Unreachable” error.
ICMP makes It possible tor network protessionals to troubleshoot network connectivity problems (with the ping
command) and track the route a packet traverses from a source IP address to a destination IP address (with the
traceroute command). Security professionals can use ICMP rype codes (see Table 2-2) to block ICMP packets from

To access entitles and services on ather networks, each computer must also have the [P address of Its gateway. Before sending a packet to another computer, the TCP/IP Internet layer uses the sending computer's subnet mask to determine
the destination computer's network address. If this address is different from the sending computer's network address,

the sending computer relays the packet to the IP address specified In the gateway parameter. The gateway computer then forwards the packet to Its next destination In this way, the packet eventually reaches the destination computer.

For example, If a Linux server has the IP address 192.168.8.2 and the subnet mask 255.255 255.0, and a user has a computer with the IP address 192.168.9200 and the subnet mask 255.255255.0, the company must conilgure a default fateway address. The delault gateway sends the message to a router, which routes It to the different network segment. IJ the detault gateway ‘sn? configured an the user's computer, and this user attempts to use the ping command ta
contact the server, the user receives the “Destinallon Unreachable” message (see Table 2-2). The user’s computer
can't connect to the other bost—a Linux server located an a dierent network segment—because there's no rautet ta
help It. The router's job is to take packets destined for a computer on a diferent network segment from the sending
computer and send them on their way.

Security professional must understand these basic network concepts before attempting to conduct a penetraUon test on a network, especially one that's been subnetted. As a security professional, you shauld spend some time reviewing the IP addressing system Internet Protocol version

caused by this aversight. This section gives you some basics of [Pv6, but reading RFC 2460 (www tetf org/rte/ric2460. bet) ls recommended for more detalls.

IPv6 was develaped to increase the IP address space and pravide additional security. Instead oi the 4 bytes used in IPv4, IPv6 uses 16 bytes, or a 128-bit address, so 2'™ addresses are available—about 2000 IP addresses far every Square foot on the planet. You might think thls many IP addresses aren't necessary, but they'll be needed to support the Internet of Things (aT). Many new products—such as toasters, microwaves, refrigerators, and TVs—can be accessible via the Internet and need IP addresses.

Here's an example of an IPv6 number: 1211:0¢b67°75a20110:1234:3a2e 1113:777T. If lt looks odd to you, a review of hexadecimal numbers might refresh your memary. The calons separate each group of four hexadecimal numbers. The good news is thal being an effective security tester doesn’t require being an expert at translating or memorizing these long numbers.
As a security tester, you should be aware thal all newer 0s are canflgured to enable IPv6, but some router-iltering
devices, firewalls, and intruston detection systems (IDSs) are not. This makes It poesible for hackers to bypass these

security systems using IPv6. You can find numerous articles online that discuss the weaknesses with IPv4, [Pv6, and the protocals that support them Cyber attackers spend haurs reading these types oi articles. Security testers shauld, too.

Reviewing the Binary Numbering System

You learned base-10 math in elementary school, although you might not have reallzed it at the time. When you see the number 3742, for example, you recognize it as “three thousand seven hondred and forty-two.” By placing each number in a calumn, as shawn in the following lines, you can see thal each number has a dilferent value and magnitude. This numbering system uses 10 as its base and goes irom right to left, multiplying the base number In each calumn by an
exponent, starting from zero. Valid numbers in base 10 are 0 thraugh 9. That is, each column can contain any number
fram Oto 9.
As you can see, you get 3742 by multiplying 2 by 1, 4 by 10, 7 by 100, and 3 by 1000, and then adding all these
values. The binary numbering system, an the other hand, uses 2 as its base. Each binary digit (bir) is represented by

a 1 or O. Bits are usually grouped by eight because a byte contalns 8 bits. Computer engineers chose this nombering system because logic chips make binary decisions based an true ar false, on or off, and similar conditions. With 8 bits,
a programmer can represent 256 dlilerent colors for a video card, tor example. (Two to the power af eight, or 2°, equais
256.) Therefore, black can be represented by 00000000, white by 1111111), and so an.
Another example of using binary numbering can be seen In file permissions for users: r (read), w (write), and
x (execute). A | represents having the permission, and a 0 removes the permission Therefore, 111 (ewx) means
all permissions apply, and 101 (r-x) means the user can read and execute the file but not write to it. (The - symbol
indicates that the permission isn’t granted.) Those famillar with Unix will recognize this numbering system. Unix

allows using the decimal equivalent af binary numbers, so for the binary 111, you enter the decimal number 7. For the binary 10], you enter the decimal number 5. Confused? You'll be a binary expert In a jew minutes, so hang In there.

To simplify the concept of binary numbers, think of a room with rwo ight switches, and consider how many diflerent combinations al pasitions you could use for the switches. Changing Permissions with the chmod Command in Unix and Linux systems, the chmod command allows you to alter the permissions of Mes and directortes. This is useful If you need to pravide more ar less permissions to a Mle or directory for securtty purposes.

You can use chaod ta change permlasions in two main ways. One way is to provide the permissions as an octal number. For example, to change the permissions ol the file bello.bct so that the owner, group, and other members have full read, write, and execute permissions, enter the Jollowing command:
od 777 hello txt

Remember that 7 octal In binary is 111, which means the r, w, and x bits are all enabled, giving read, write, and execure permigslons. The first T in 777 gives the owner full rwx permissions, the second 7 gives the group full rwx permissions, and the final 7 gives other full rwx permissions.
Uf you want to change permissions so that other users bave no permission at all Jor the file hello.txt, use the falJowing command:
od 770 hello txt
U you want to change permissions so thar the awner has read and write permlaslons, the group has read permissions, and other has execute permissions, use the following command:
od 641 hello.tzt
Keep in mind that the chined 641 hello. txt command completely changes all the permissions you set with
ed 770 hello. txt.
Besides providing a full three-digit octal permission number, chmad allows you to target speciiic permissian sets
(owner, group, or other) and turn individual read, write, or execute permissions on or off. To do this, you need to
specify who you are setting permissions for, what change are you making (adding or removing the permission), and
which permission you are setting. You may find dls targeted approach more convenlent.
The “who” values you can use are the fallowing:
uw: User, meaning the owner of the fle
Group, meaning members of the group the file belangs ta

a: All, meaning all of the above
The “what” values you can use are the following:
— Minus sign to remove the permission
Phis sign to grant the permission
= Equals sign to set a permission and remove others.
The “which” valpes you can use are the following:
r: Read permission
w: Write permission
a Execute permission

Besides using antivinis soltware ta combat malware, security professionals use network security devices and sandbaxing. Network security devices can monitor entire networks and intercept malware before It reaches users. Sandboxing allows users to run programs in a secure, isolated operating area that prevents malictous files from being written to the hard drive. Sandboxing Is often used by security professionals to safely test whether a file has malware.

As the name implies, a denial-of-service (DoS) attack prevents legitimate users irom accessing network resources. In a DoS attack, attackers aren't altempting to access the Information an a remate computer. However, they might be
using the attack ta cripple the network.

AS a secunity tester, you don’t usually install a virus or worm on a ciistomer’s computer as part af your testing. Similarty, you shauld know how a DoS attack can lake place and attempt to protect a company from it, but conducting

the attack yourself lan’t wise. Doing so wauld be like a safety consultant blowing up a refinery after being hired to look for safety hazards. You simply need to explain haw the attack could be carried out.
An oki but useful example of a DoS attack Is the Ping of Death attack. This attack causes the victim computer
to freeze and malfunction. It ls nat as common as It was during the late 1990s. The attacker creates an (CMP packet
larger than the maximun-allowed 65,535 bytes. The large packet ls Iragmented into smaller packets and reassembled
at its destination. The uset’s system at the destination point can’t handle the reassembled oversized packet, thereby
causing the system to crash or freeze This is alsa an example of a bufler overflow attack, which ls discussed later in
this module.
Distributed Denial-of-Service Attacks
A distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack is launched against a host fram multiple servers or workstations. Ina

DDoS attack, a network could be flooded with billions of packets: typically, each participant in the attack sends only a few of the tata] nomber of packets. [f one server bombards an attacked server with hundreds or even thousands of

packets, available network bandwidth couki drop to the point that legitimate users natice a performance degradation. Now imagine 1000 servers or even 10,000 distributed servers involved, with each server sending several thousand [P
packets to the attacked server. There you have it: a DDoS attack

Keep in mind that participants in the attack often aren’t aware thelr computers are taking part in the attack. They, too, have been attacked by the culprit In jact, in one DDoS attack, a company was Dooded with IP packets fom thousands of Internet routers and web servers belonging to Yahoo.com.

A Dark DDoS attack is a smoke screen to distract netwark defenders while another stealthler and likely more damaging attack ts occurring. By focusing network defenders on a sustalned “noisy” DDoS aftack, the attacker can carry out a fraudulent transaction or exilitration of data that might have been caught If the defenders had not focused on the DDoS.

Each year, Department of Defense (DoD) employees are required to complete security awareness training that emphssizes the dangers of terrorists and sples being able co collect unclassified Information. This Infarmacian can be found In

Newspapers, websites, and TV and radio news programs, but k can also be gathered fram Facebook, Linkedin, and Twitter. By combining small pieces of information, terrorists can create a fairly detailed picture of the DoD's activites. The DoD wants its employees to realize that discussing seemingly inconsequendal Information might be more dangerous than

Imagined. This information, when combined with Information from other sources, can be damaging to national security. For example, a sallor in the U.S. Navy meets a friendIna restaurant and mengions that he'll be gone for six months. At
the same restaurant, a cMilan working for the DoD mentions (0 a friend over lunch that she has to work overtime ordering

supplies. As you can see, terrortsts could easily pick up both pleces of information by listening in on conversations. This example might sound far-fetched, but k’s a major method of gathering Intelligence. The poind ls that you, too, need to pay attendon to all information that’s available, whether It's on a website, in email haaders, or In an employee's stacement in an interview. Using Other Methods to Gather Information Sa fay, you have learned several methods tor gathering Information bom company websites and emall addresses. With anly a URL, you can determine which web server and O5 a company ls using and learn the names of IT personnel, tar example. You need to be aware of ather methods attackers use to gather information about a company. Some of these methods, such as using coakies and web beacons, are unscrupulous. A web bug Is ane type al web beacon. Detecting Cookies and Web Bugs A cookie is a text le generated by a web server and stored on a user's brawser. The inJarmation in this ble is sent to the web server when the user returns to the website. For example, a returning customer can be shown a customized webpage when he or she revisits an online store’s website. Some coaktes can cause security Issues because unscne pulous people might stare persanal Information in cookies thal can be used ta attack a computer or server. Other cookles stare sensitive information (such as user credentials) unencrypted.
A wehb bug Is a )-pixel x L-pixel Image file referenced in an <IMG» tag, and it usually works with a cooke. It ls one

type af web beacon, a hidden graphic or plece of code embedded in a webpage ta track user activity and harvest user information. The purpase al a web bug Is similar to that af spyware and adware: to collect information about the person visiting the website, such as an JP address, when the web bug was viewed, and the type of browser used to view the

page All this information can be useful to hackers. Web bugs are nat from the same wehslte as the webpage creator. They came Irom third-party companies specializing in data collecttan. Because web bugs are a type of standard Image
file, usually a GIF, they can't be blocked by a brawser or rejected by a user. Also, web bugs usually match the color of the webpage’s background, which renders them Invisible.
Anather form af web beacon embeds JavaScript code into the webpages oj a website. Thal JavaScript code returns
tracking Information to a datagathering organization. This type of web beacon ls also hidden from the user becaime
it is part of the backgraund cade of a webpage and Is not visible.
Uf you don’t have a tool for detecting web bags or JavaScript web beacons, ane way to find them is by examining
the webpage's saurce code to find a file in an tag loading from a web server different from ather image files on the

page. Using a different server might Indicate that the image file ls a web bug. Alsa look for pleces of JavaScript that seem to be collecting and sending data to known data-harvesting organizations. Another way to detect web beacons
is to check the network connections on a machine (perhaps using netstat) or capture network trafic (perhaps using
Wireshark) and see li data ls being sent ta mown data-harvesting arganizations. In Activity 4-5, you research the topic

af web beacons. As you do, you will likely discover who these “data-harvesting organizations” are. Security profeasionak need to be aware of cookies and web beacons to keep these infarmation-gathering toals off company computers.

The toals you've just learned abou aren’t the only way to collect Information. Sometimes information about a company Is gathered using nontechnical skills. In fact, the best hackers aren't necessarily the most technically adept people Instead, they possess a more Insidious—and often underestimated—skill called social engineering, discumsed in the following section.
INTRODUCTION TO SOCIAL ENGINEERING

You can gather intelligence without using hacking tools, or Intelligence-gathering software. One nontechnical method of collecting information Is called social engineering. Social engineering uses the art of deception to extract valuable information irom well-meaning people who are trying to be helplul The best detense against soclal engineering ls user training becanse the object being hacked for Information ls a person and not a computer. Training users so they are aware of soclal engineering tactics is your best defense.
The art of soclal engineering bas been aroond much longer than computers.
Social engineering uses knowledge of human nature to gather information from people. In computer attacks, the

information is usually a password to a network or other Information an attacker could use to compromise a network. A salesperson, Jor example, can gather personal Information about customers, such as income, hobbies, social ble, amd music preferences, by asking the customer the right questions. The salesperson uses communication skills to connect to customers and craft a message that persuades customers to buy a product or service. Social engineers might use similar persuasion tactics along with Intimidation, coercion, extortion, and even blackmall to gather the information they need. Social engineers are probably the biggest security threat to networks and the moet difficult to Protect agalnst.

You have probably heard the saying “Why try to crack a password when you can shnply ask tor it?” Many attackers do Just that: They ask users for passwords and other credentials. Unfortunately, many users give attackers everything they need to break into a network Most people who have worked at a help desk or in network support Imow this to be true. Even if a company policy states that passwords must not be given to anyone, users olten think this policy doesn’t apply to IT personnel and recite their passwords out loud when an IT technician is seated in front of thelr computers. TT personnel don’t want to know a user's password. They especially don’t want a user to say It aloud or type it in email Mhessages. Yet users often don’t consider their company passwords private, so they don’t guard them as carefully as they might for personal passwords or PINs. Users might not think thar the data they store on their company’s computers would be oi interest to an attacker Social engineers know how to put these types of users al ease. The Art of Shoulder Surfing Another method social engineers use to gain arcess to information is shoulder surfing. A shoulder surier ls skilled at reading what users enter on thelr keyboards, es pecially logon names and passwords. Shoulder surfers also use this sill 1a read PINs entered on ATM keypads, or passcode numbers used to apen doors with keypad locks. Keypad number theft. is easter than computer shoulder surilng because a keypad has fewer characters to memorize than a computer keyboard. SECURITY BYTES A common tactic of shoulder surfers Is using smartphone cameras to take photos of unaware shoppers’ credit cards In supermarkets and stores. With this technique, they can capture the credit card number and expiration date. Combining this cechnique with obsening the shopper entering a PIN increases the risk of idendty theft.

Many Keyboard users don’t tallow the traditional fingering technique taught in typing classes. Instead, they bunt and peck with two or three fingers. However, shoulder surfers train themselves to memorize key positlans on a standard keyboard. A standard keyboard could be a physical or virtual keyboard an a computer or mobile device. Armed witb this knowledge, shoulder surfers can determine which keys are pressed by noticing the location an the keyboard, not which finger the typist is using.

smal] pleces makes It possible for attackers to break Into a network The Art of Piggybacking Sometimes security testers need to enter part of a building that’s restricted to authorized personnel. In this case, a tester or an attacker uses a technique called piggybacking. Piggybacking is trailing closely behind an employee who has access to an area without the employee realizing you didn’t use a PIN or a security badge to enter the area Those skilled in plggybacking watch authorized personnel enter secure areas and walt for the opportune time to Jain them quickly at the security entrance. They count on human nature and the desire of athers to be palite and hold open a secured door. This play usually works, especially li the plggybacker has both hands full and seems to be struggling to remove an access card tram a purse or pants pocket. Some plggybackers wear a jake badge around their necks or pretend to scan a security card across a card reader. Il they're detected, they might say thelr card has been giving them problems and use thelr social-engineering skills to canvince the security
guard to let them through.

A good preventive measure against piggybacking is using turnstiles at areas where plagybacking can occur. However, the best preventive measure is to train personnel to natify security when they notice a stranger In a restricted area. Employees must feel a vested Interest In area security and should nat rely on security personnel. Employees should be taught not to hold secured doors open for anyone, even peaple they know. Educate your users to get In the habit of making sure all employees use thelr access cards to enter a restricted area and to report any suspiclous or unknown peaple to security.

As a security tester, you need to know which ports attackers are going after so yay can close and protect those ports. Security testers must scan all ports when dalng a test, nat Just the well-imown ports. Many programs use part numbers outside the range of well-known ports. For example, TeamViewer, a wellimown PC remote contro! program, aperates on ports 5938, 443, and 80. A hacker who discovers that port 5938 is open can check the Information at the CVE website Jor a possible vulnerability in Team Viewer. After a hacker discovers an apen service, finding a vulnerability or exploit is nat difficult, especially when systems are out of date and unpatched.
SECURITY BYTES
Most security testers and hackers argue that port scanning és legal simply because ht doesn: dwade others privacy; lt merely

Ciscovers whether the party being scanned bs avallable. The typical analogy is a person walking down the street and tumning the doorknob of every house along the way. Hf the door opens, the person notes that the door Is open and proceeds to the next house. Of course, entering che house ts 3 crime in most parts of che world, Just as entering a computer or network system without the owner's permission is a crime. To date, no ane has heen comécted just for port scanning In the United States, akhough some laws call for prosecuting scanning Hf It causes damage ov loss of more than $5000 (U.S. Code 18 1030).

Port scanning belps you answer questions about apen ports and services by enabling yau to scan thousands or even tens of thansands of IP addresses quickly. Many port-scanning tools produce reports of thelr findings, and some give you best-quess assessments af which OS Is running on a system. Most, if not all, scanning programs report open ports, clased ports, and filtered ports In a matter af seconds. An open part allows access to applications and can be vulnerable ta an attack When a web server needs to communicate with applications or other camputers, for example, port 443 ls opened. A closed port doesn't allow entry or access to a service. Far instance, li ports 443 and
80 are clased on a web server, users can’t access websites. A port reported as filtered might indicate thar a flrewall is being used to allow specibed traffic into or out af the netwark.

Types of Port Scans Betore delving Lnto using port-scanning taok, Jook at the types of scans that can be used for port scanning: © SYN scan—tn a normal TCP session, a packet is sent to another computer with the SYN Mag set. The recelvIng computer sends back a packet with the SYN/ACK flag set, Indicating an acknowledgment. The sending computer then sends a packet with the ACK flag set. i the SYN packet ls sent to a cloced port, the computer
responds with an RST/ACK (reset/acknowledgment) packet [f an attacker’s computer receives a SYN/ACK

MODULES PORT SCANNING a packet, It responds quickly with an RST/ACK packet, closing the session This is done so that a full TCP connection is never made and logged as a transaction In this sense, it's “stealthy.” After all, attackers don’t want a transactlon logged showing thelr connection to the attacked computer and Esting their IP addresses.
Connect scan—This type of scan relies on the attacked computer's OS, so it’s niskler to use A connect scan is

similar to a SYN scan, except that it completes the three-way handshake. This means the attacked computer most likely logs the transaction or connection, Indicating that a session took place. Therefore, unlike a SYN scan, a Connect scan isn’t stealthy and can be detected easily.

@ MULL scan—in a NULL scan, all packet Gags are turned off A clased port responds toa NULL scan with an RST packet, so #f no packet is received, the best guess is that the port ls open. Windows, however, does not follow the standard and might respond in an unexpected way.

e XMAS scon—in this type o/ scan, the FIN, PSH, and URG Bags are set. Closed ports respond to this type ol packet with an RST packet This scan can be used to determine which ports are open For example, an attacker could send this packet to port 53 on a system and see whether an RST packet Is returned. If not, the DNS port might be open. Agaln, Windows does not Iollow the standard and responds randomly to XMAS scans.

© ACK scan—Attackers typically use ACK scans to get past a firewall or other diltering device. A filtering device looks for the SYN packet, the first packet in the three-way handshake, that the ACK packet was part of Remember this packet order: SYN, SYN/ACK, and ACK. Hi the aftacked port returns an RST packet, the packet flter was fooled, or there's no packet-Hltering device. In either case, the attacked port is considered to be “unfiltered.”

© FIN scon—in this type of scan, a FIN packet is sent to the target computer. I the port Is cased, it sends back an RST packet When a three-way handshake ends, both partles send a FIN packet to end the connection.

© UDP scen—Iin this rype of scan, 4 UDP packet Is sent to the target computer. Ef the port sends back an [CMP “Port Unreachable” message, the port is closed. Again, not receiving that message might Imply the port is open, bot this isn’t always true. A Mlrewall or packetiltering device could undermine your assumptions.
Acomputer that receives a SYN packet trom a remote computer responds with a SYN/ACK packet Hi Its port is open.
In a three-way handshake, a SYN packet is sent fom one computer, a SYN/ACK Is sent from the recelving computer to

the sender, and finally, the sender sends an ACK packet to the receiving computer. If a port ls cloeed and receives a SYN packet, it sends back an RST/ACK packet Determining whether a port is Mltered is more complex. Many scanning
tools, such as Nmap, use a best-guess approach. Thar is, if a UDP packet doesn’t receive a response from the receiving

port, many scanning tools report that the port is open. SECURITY BYTES In Canada, a man was found guilty of scanning a company’s computers. The company prosecuted him for using mirowatts Of Its electrical power to perform the scan. Doing so without the company’s permission was consktered a crime—petty,
yes, but effective. To play k safe, always get permission from a company If you're going to perform an intensive scan on ks

network infrastructure. If your scan dows down a network's traffic, the company might argue that a low-level DoS attack, which ts illegal, was performed. USING PORT-SCANNING TOOLS Hundreds of port-scanning tools are available for both hackers and security testers. Some are commercial, and some are freeware or open source. How do you decide which tool to use? Not all are accurate, so using more than one portscanning tool ls recommended. In addition, becoming famillar with a variety of tools ls wise. ANhough you should practice often with a tool to gain proficiency in using It, don’t fall into the trap of using one tool exclusively. Nmap Originally written for Phrack magazine In 1997 by Pyodor, Nmag has become one of the most popular port scanners and adds new Jealures constantly, such as OS detection and fast multiple-probe ping scanning. Nmap also has a GUI front end called Zenmap that makes working with complex options easier Nmap has been enhanced over the years because,

like many other security tools, it’s open source; i bugs are found, users can offer suggestions far correcting them. Copyright 2023 Cengage Laaming. AS Rignts Reserved. May not be copied, scanned, of dupacated, in whole or in past. WCN 02-200-203a SP cP aA SS A OPO

Nmap Is referred to often in this course because it's currently the standard port-scanning tool for security professionals. Regardless of the ather part-scanning tools available, any security tester with a modicum of experience has worked with Nmap. As a beginning student, you can use it during every part of a security or penetration test but remember to build proficiency In a variety af tools.
SECURITY BYTES

AS Most security professionals will tell you, Holywood seldom depicts attackers actually hacking into a system. Typically, they're using a GUI program, frantically clicking, or typing a decryption algorithm. One excepdon Is The Matrix Reloaded The
female protagonist, Trinity, sits at a computer terminal and runs Nmap. She discovers that port 22 (SSH) is open, nuns an
SSHv1 CRC 32 explok (an actual bug in SSH) that alows her to change the root password to Z10N0101, and then proceeds
to shut dowm the grid. Moral of che story? Know your tools and exploits, and you might save the world.

You don’t have to memorize how each Nag is set when running a part scan with Nmap. in Jact, just typing the command nmap 193.145.85.2 01 scans common ports on the computer with this [IP address. However, port
ecanning can be an Involved process. Some attackers want to be hidden from network devices ar ID6s that recognize

an inordinate number of pings or packets being sent to thelr networks, so they use stealth attacks and limit thelr scan speeds to make thelr activities more difficult to detect. In addition to these techniques, an attacker could target anly a few ports instead of scanning all common ports. In the following activitles, you become famillar with the basic Nmap commands and then learn some of the more complex options.

Port scanners can also be used to conduct a ping sweep of a large network to identify which IP addresses belong ta active hosts. In other words, to find out which hosts are “live.” ping sweeps simply ping a range of IP addresses
and see what type of response Is returned. The problem with relying on ping sweeps to identify live hosts (s that a

computer might be shut down at the time ol the sweep and indicate that the IP address doesn’t belong to a lve host. Another problem with ping sweeps is that many network administrators configure nodes to not respond to an ICMP
Echo Request (type 8) with an [CMP Echo Reply (type 0). This response doesn’t mean the computer (sn’t running: it

just means it isn’t replying to the attack computer. Add the possibility of a firewall filtering out ICMP traffic, and you have many reasons for using caution when running ping sweeps. You can use many tools to conduct a ping sweep of a network, and you learn about some in the following sections. Fping
With the Fping tool (wwwfping. org), you can ping multiple IP addresses simultaneously. Fping, included with Kali

Linuy, can accept a range of IP addresses entered at a command prompt, or you can Create a Mle containing multiple IP addresses and use it as Input for the Fping command. For example, the fping -f£ ip addresa .txt command

uses (p_address. txt, which contains a list of IP addresses, as its input Me. The input file is usually created with a shellscripting language so that you don’t need to type the thousands ol IP addresses needed for a ping sweep on a Class B
network, for example. Figure 5-6 shows some parameters you can use with the Fping command. | Figure 5-6 Fping parameters Source? GNU Public License

To ping sweep a range of IP addresses without using an input file, you use the command fping -g BeginningiPAddress Ending! PAddress. The -g parameter Is used when no Input Iile is available For example, the fping -g 192.168.165.1 192.1668.185.5 command returns the results shawn in Figure $7. Hping3 You can also use the Hping3 tool to perform ping sweeps. However, many security testers use it to bypass filtering devices by injecting crafted or otherwise modified [IP packets. Windows systems after Windows T. Table 6-1 describes Windows 05s from Windows 95 to Windows Server 2019. Table 6-1 Windows 05 descriptions

Windows 95 The first Microsoft GUI product that doesn't rety an DOS, Windows 95 Is the beginning of plug and play and the ActiveX standard used in all Windows versions today. A major enhancement is the Registry, a database storing information about the system's hardware and software. Previously, this information was stored in files. Windows 95 runs on stand-alone and networked Computers and uses the FAT16 file system. Version OSR2 adds support for FAT32.
Windows 98 and Me Compared to thelr predecessors, these versions have an improved file systern (FAT32),
new hardware support, and better backup and recovery cools. The enumeration process for Windows Me Is the same as for Windows 98.
Windows NT 3.51 Server/ | These OSs were created with security and enhancement of network functionality in
Workstation mind. They emphasize domains instead of workgroups and use the dient/server model
instead of peer-to-peer networks; the server is responsible for authenticating users

and giving them access to network resources. The dient/server model also allows for having many computers in a domain instead of the imited number of computers in a workgroup. NTFS replaces FAT16 and FAT32 because of the difficulty in incorporating security in the eartier file systems. NTFS includes file-level sequrity features not possible in FAT.
Windows NT 4.0 Servers These upgrades to Windows NT 3.51 have Improved GUks and performance.
Workstation
Windows 2000 Server/ In this upgrade to NT, Microsoft indudes Active Directory (AD) for object storage. AD
Professional is more scalable than other available solutions for managing large networks. It uses
Lighoweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP), which ts still in use today. Also, this update
indudes the first version of Migosoft Management Console (MMC} and Encrypted File
System (EFS). Enumeration of these OSs indudes enumerating Active Directory.

Windows XP Professional | This OS includes Windows 2000 features, such as standards-based security, improved manageablity, and the MMC. In addition, Windows XP has an improved user Interface and better plug-and-play support. Security improvements in the kemel data syuctures
make them read-only to prevent rogue applications from affecting the OS core,
and Windows File Protection is added to prevent overwrtting core system files. With
Service Pack 2 (SP2), security ts improved further with features such as Data Exeaution
Prevention (DEP) and a firewall enabled by default. DEP fixes a seaurtty exposure caused

by vulnerable running services that hackers often use for buffer averflow attacks, and the firewall makes it more difficult for hackers co explolt Windows service vulnerabilities and enumerate shares and services. In fad, enumeration of Windows XP SP2 and later systems can be difficult without modifying the configuration, Disabling the Windows Firewallis common in corporate networks, but thts pracdce gives hackers addidonal attack surface. In chese environments, the enumeration processes used for eariler Windows versions still work much the same way in Windows XP Professtanal.
Windows Server 2003 Windows Server 2003 indudes improvements over Windows 2000 in some sequrity
areas, such as Intemet Information Services (11S}, and comes in four editions. Generally,
all editions indude Remote Desktop, load balancing, VPN support, management services

Directory as well as enhancements to reflability, scalability, manageability, and seawity. Even with improvements in security and stability, enumeration techniques described for other Windows versions are effeaive with Windows Server 2003.

Many of the enumeration techniques that work with older Windows OSs still work with the newer versions. NetBIOS Basics Belore learning bow to enumerate Micrasoh systems, you need to review the basics of bow Network Basic Input/
Gueput System (NetBIOS) works. NetBIOS Ls a Windows programming interface that allaws computers to communicate
across a local area network (LAN). Most Windaws OSs use NetBIOS to share files and printers. NetBIOS Ilstens on UDP
ports 137 (NetBIOS Name service} and 138 (NetBIOS Datagram service) and TCP port 139 (NetBIOS Session service}.
File and printer sharing in Windows also requires an upper-teve] service called Server Message Block (SMB), which
Funs on top af NetBIOS. In Windows 2000 and later, SMB listens an TCP port 445 and doesn't need to use NetBIOS over TCP/IP unless support for older Windows versions is required.
NOTE
Enumeration bs a process of discovery. Using one enumeration tool may lead to a discovery that directs you to use another
enumeration tool For example, if you had used Nmap and laamed that a device had UPD ports 137 and 138 and TCP
Port 139 (all che Net8IOS ports) open, you might chen use a NetBIOS enumeration tool such as NBTscan to see what more
you could discover about that device.
The computer names you assign to Windows systems are called NetBIOS names and have a limit of 16 characters;

the last character ls reser ved for a hexadecimal number (00 to FF) that Identifies the service running an the computer. Therefore, you can use anty 15 characters for a computer name, and NetBIOS adds the last character automatically to
Jdentify the service that has registered with the 05. For example, if a computer is running the Server service, the OS stores this Information in a NetBIOS table.

A NetBIOS name must be unique on a network. Table 6-2 lists the NetBiOS suffixes that correspond to the services, or resource types, running on a computer You dan't need to memorize all these suffixes but note that some identify the computer ar server being enumerated as a stand-alone computer or domain controller. Hackers often exert more eitart to attack computers identlihed as domain contrallers because these systems store more information, Including Jogon names far user accounts and network resources. You can perfarm an Internet search to find a more comprehenSive list af NetBIOS sulfixes.

NetBIOS Null Sessions Historically, one of the biggest vulnerabilities of NetBIOS systems Is a null session, which ts an unauthenticated con nection to a Windows computer that uses no logon and password values. Many enumeration tool covered in this
module establish a null session to gather information such as logon accounts, group membership, and file shares from

an attacked computer. This vulnerabillty has been around for more than a decade and Is still present in Windows XP. Null sesstons have been disabled by default in Windows Server 2003, although administrators can enable them If they are needed for some reason. In Windows Vista and Server 2008, null sessions aren't available and can’t be enabled, even by administrators. You might ask, “Why are we talking about these ancient operating systems? Who uses Windows XP anymore?” You would be surprised. If you as a penetration tester find an older operating system, you have just discovered a major security vulnerability as these operating systems are no longer supported and do not receive security updates. Your courses af action include upgrading the operating system, Isolating the vulnerable ancient OS so It is not connected to any networks, or decommissioning the system. NetBIOS Enumeration Tools The nbt stat command is a powerlul enumeration tool included with Windows. To display the NetBIOS table, you
issue the nbt stat -a IPaddreas command. (If you want to run Nbtstat locally, the command fs nbt stat -s.) Figure
6-2 shows the entry LON-DC1. The 20 represents the Server service running on the LON-DC1 computer. The NetBIOS table also shows that ADATUM fs a domain controller, as indicated by the IC suffix

Another builtin Windows tool is the net: view command, which gives you a quick way to see whether there are any shared resources on a Computer or server. To display the syntax for this command, type net view >. Using the net view command. an attacker can view remote shares. as shown in Figure 6-3.

You can also use the IP address of computers you discovered with port-scanning tools. For example, Figure 64 shows the command used on a remote Windows 10 computer A share name called wow bs displayed. The next command an atlacker could use against this computer is \\robt.binkpad3 2gb\wow to explore the share drive and look for Interesting files.

Although you can download or buy enumeration tools, you should learn how to take advantage of the tools available in Windows. A simple command-line ulflity can give you the name af a logged-on user, and a guess of that user's password can give you access to the system quickly Many password-cracking programs can determine a password in a matter of seconds. A quick Internet search will reveal many free password-cracking programs you can try. However, security testers can often guess passwords without needing a special program because some users are careless when creating passwords. For example, many users, despite guidelines in company security policies, use simple passwords, such as “password” or “p@$$wOrd.” Some systems also have detault legon credentials that users often neglect to change, such as a username of “admin” with a password that is also “admin”. You can lind Hsts of delauhk credentials for various devices on the Internet. Many password-cracking programs mentioned earlier can use brute force and attempt thousands of logons using dictionarles containing thousands of passwords. These dictionaries include wellknown poor passwords (like password 1234) and well-known default credentials.

Unforwinately, most calleges dan’t teach programming with security in mind. Many current attacks on operating systems and applications are possible because af poor programming practices. Mary Ann Davidson, Oracle's chief
secutity officer (CSO), speaks all over the world an this topic. She argues that software develapers facus an “caol

technology” and the latest programming languages. “They don’t think Ilke attackers,” she stated to an audience Milled with mare than 1,000 information assurance professionals. “Nor ‘s there a requirement for software developers to demonstrate proficiency In safe, secure programming as a condition af matriculation,” she added.

Detalls on this Issue are beyond the scape of this book, but if you decide to pursue pragramming or software engineering as a major, urge the college you're attending to caver secure programming. Oracle’s CSO ollered some suggestions to change the higher education system. She believes security shauld be part of every computer science class, “nat just in a single clacs thar students file and forget,” and computer sclence textbooks should be written to emphasize secure programming techniques. Grades should be based in part on the “hackabillity” of code students

subanit for assignments, and students should be required to use automated toals to find vulnerabilities in thelr coding. Security must be Integrated Into any sottware engineering project from lts inception, not after the fact. A new Beld in

cybersecurity called SecDevOps attempts to adjust the mindset af programmers to develop code with security and IT operations in mind. The term SecDevOps stands lor security, development, and operatians. Developing cade with security in mind and understanding IT operations result in more robust and explolt-resistant software. instead of adding security by changing someone else's code to make it more secure, SecDevOps attempts to have the original developers “bake” security Into code fram the start.

Bogs are worse than syntax errors because a program can run successfully ‘with a bug, but the outpur might be incorrect or inconsistent Performing tasks Ln the Incorrect order might also create havoc. Software engineering companies don retain programmers who don’t document their work because they know that 80 percent of the cast of software projects ls maintenance. They also know that an average of 10 bugs for every 1,000 lines of code is the Industry standard. For example, Windows [0 1s estimated to contaln over 50 milllon Ines 04 code, but Microsoft software engineers, partly because of strict documentation rules and Secure Software Development Lifecycle Practices, can limit bugs to tewer than the average. In general, the average number of bugs in Micrasolt code 1s below the industry standard. With bugs being so prevalent in many programs, however, it's easy to see how attackers can discover vulnerabilities in software. Programmers can éasily overlook problems in thousands ol lines of code that might create a securlty bole attackers can exploit.

Print Spooler, a part of Windows that manages printing. Windows 7 has reached the end of ies life and Is no longer actively

The Python programming language was named alter the BEC TV shaw, Monfy Python's Flying Circus. Python, lke Ferl, ls a scripting language with some abject-orlented features. As a scripting language. Scripting languages don't need to be compiled because they are interpreted, and this arguably makes them Jaster when creating, testing, and executing short programs.

Ethical hackers often create programe to help automate their activities, and Python is well culted for this purpose. In fact, Python Ls growing in popularity in the ethical hacking community. Hacking libraries and toals written In Python are becoming widely available.
Python emphasizes code readability and uses Indentation to define blacks of code (not brackets and braces
like Perl or C}. Using incorrect spacing can produce a syntax errar In Python, so be sure to indent statements
correctly and cansistently. In this sectlan, you will examine the syntax af Python and practice writing Pythan scripts.

installed. Python 3.9 (released in October 2020) is a recent stable release. For more details, visit https: //en wikipedia. org/wils/Python_(programming language).

Python also has an Interactive shel] where you can enter Python commands and have them inunediately executed. This shell is also known as the REPL, which stands for Read, Evaluate, Print, Loop. REPL reads a command, evaluates the command, prints the results, and loops back to read more commands. This shell is convenient for performing quick tasks Itke calculations or performing operations by calling exdsting Junctions. NetBIOS

Recall that NetBIOS is software loaded into memory and enables a program to interact with a network resource or device. Network resources are Identified with l6-byte NetBIOS names. NetBIOS Isn’t a protocol: It’s the interface to a network protocol that enables a program to access a network resource. It usually works with NeeBiOS Extended
User Interface (NetBEUI). a fast, efficient protocol that requires little configuration and allows transmitting NetBIOS
packets over TCP/IP and various network topologies. NetBJOS aver TCPAP Is disabled by default on current versions of Windows but was enabled by default prior to Windows Vista and Server 2008.

Systems running newer Windows OSs can share files and resources without using NetBIOS: however. NetBIOS is still used for backward compartbility, which is important when organizational budgets don’t allow upgrading every computer on the networic In addition, customer expectations must be met. For example, customers expect that a document created In Word 2010 can stil] be read In Word 2019. In fact, they demand it. Therefore, software developers face the challenge of improving OS security while ensuring compatibility with less secure predecessors. As long as newer Windows OSs must work with older NetBIOS-based systems. security will be a challenge.

Common internet File System (CIFS) is a standardized protocol that replaced SMB in Windows 2000 Server, but ta

CIFS Ls a remote file system protocol that enables computers to share network resources over the Internet. In other words, files, folders, printers, and ather resources can be made available to users throughout a network. For sharing
10 occur, the network must have an infrastructure that allows placing these resources on the network and a method

16 control access 10 resources. CIFS reiles on ather protocols 1o handle service announcements notilying users what resources are available on the network and tao handle authentication and authorization far accessing these resources. CIFS is also available for many *nlx systems.

Recall that a buller overflow occurs when data Is written to a bufler (temporary memory space) and, because

of Insuiliclent bounds checking, corrupts data in memory next to the allocated bulfer. Normally, this problem occurs when dangerous functions use input that bas not been properly validated. Passwords and Authentication You've already learmed that the weakest security link in any network is authorized users. Unfortunately, this link is the mast dilficult to secure, as It relles on people who might not reallze that their actions could expose their organization

10 a major security breach, resulting ln damaged systems, stolen or destrayed information, malware infection, and sa forth. There might also be legal issues to deal with after an attack, and a company can lose customers’ confidence as a result.

Companies should take steps to address this vulnerabillty. A comprehensive password policy is critical, as a username and passward are often all that stands between an attacker and access. A password policy should inclode the fallowing:
@ Change passwords regularly an system-level accounts.

« Require users to change their passwords quarterly. While this can be a sound practice that many security professionals advocate, some securlty organizations suggest that frequent password changes make lor less secure passwords as users tend to change their passwords Ln a predictable fashion, such as incrementally changing a number. Also, frequent password changes may encourage users to use the same password for ditlerent lagans. Therefore, these organizations have suggested removing the password change requirement.
© Require a minimum password length of af least eight characters (and 15 characters Jor administrative
accounts).

« Require complex passwords: in other words, passwords must Include both uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, symbok, and punctuation characters. However, some security organizations suggest that longer passwords are better than complex passwords. Hackers and their automated tools can guess substltutions af
$ for S or @ for A, so that type of complexity doesn’t enhance secuntry. Because longer passwords take longer
1a crack, security experts suggest abandoning complexity In favor of length.
« Passwords can’t be common words, words found in the dictionary (In any language}, or slang, jargon, or
dialect.
© Passwords must nat be Identifed with a particular user, such as birthdays, names, or campany-telated wards.
« Never write a password down or store Lt online or in a file on the user’s compurer
© Don’t hint at or reveal a password to anyone over the phone, in email, ar in person.
© Require users to take cautlon when logging on to make sure no ane sees them entering a password.
© Limit reuse of old passwords.

BEST PRACTICES FOR HARDENING WINDOWS SYSTEMS

As a penetration tester, your Job is to find vulnerabilities and report them as defined in your contract Your responsibility ends there. However, security testers must not only find vulnerabilities; they must be familar with methods
at correcting then. Typically, managers want solutions Included with reports of potential problems, particularly tor technologies they might not fully understand.

Although the only way to make a system truly secure Is to unplug it and lock #t away in a vault, this approach defies the purpase of a network Because you can’t lock network computers away to Keep them secure, the best option Is to be vigilant A security breach Ls only one undiscovered vulmerabiliry away, but with careful management, most systems. can be secured adequately and still meet users’ needs. General practices Jor making and keeping a network secure are discussed In the following sections.
Patching Systems

The best way to keep systems secure, operating at peak performance, and using the newest features is 10 Aeep systems under your care up to date. As noted, many aftacks have taken advantage of a known vulnerability that has a patch

avallable. There are several methods for obtaining service packs, hotfixes, and patches. ¥ you have only a Jew computers to maintaln (10 or fewer), accessing Windows Update manually from each campoter works fine, but this method

is still tle consuming. Depending on the Windows version, you can configure Automatic Updates on each machine. This option is usually better because It helps ensure that machines are always up to date without the administrator or user's Intervention. The downside is thal some patches can cause problems, so testing a patch belore applying it
a production system Is preferable, particularly in large networks.
For a large network, applying updates. manually isn’t feasible Configuring Automatic Updates is an option if you

have physical access to all computers, though downloading patches to each machine can slow network pertormance. You have a couple of options for patch management. From 1994 to 2005, Microsoft's Systems Management Server (SM5)
was the standard for managing Windows security patches on multiple computers In a network This service assessed
machines in a defined domain and could be configured to manage patch deployment. (Although this service had many
other capabilities, for the purposes of this module, you only need to know that ft can be used for patch management )
In 2005, Windows Software Update Services {WSUS) became available. WSUS is a client/server technology
designed 10 manage palching and updating system software from the network. Instead of downloading updates to each

computer, WSUS downloads paiches and publishes them internally to servers and desktop systems. Unilke Automatic Updates, which downloads and installs updates automatically, the administrator has control over which updates are deployed. This feature Is a major advantage, considering that some updates can cause problems with certaln network and application contiguratlons and should be tested betore being deployed.
In 2007, Windows System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM) became the new standard. SCCM includes a

suite of tools to help administrators deploy and manage servers alongside updated patch-management functionality. SCCM even allows for administrators to control mobile devices running Android, IOS, and Windows Mobile OS.

Third-party patch-management solutions are also available from vendors such as BigFlx, Tanium, and BladeLogtc. Whatever patch-management tools you use, remember that keeping systems up to date Is one of the most critical steps

in keeping systems secure. As a security tester, you'll often find that patches aren’t current on the system you're testing. An effective patch-management scheme might seem Ilke common sense, but administrators can be so busy with other complicated issues that they forget the simple solutions. You must recommend effective patch management to your cllents and be able to explain why It's crucial to system security.
Antivirus Solutions Whether you're working with an enterprise network consisting of thousands o/ servers and tens af thousands of clients
or a smal) business network of 15 systems and one server, you must use an antivirus solution For small networks,

desktop antivirus tools with automatic updating might be enough, but in a large network, a corporatedevel solution Is Copyrighs 2023 Cengage Laarning AQ Rights Resarved Msy not De capled, scanmed, or dupécatod, In whole cr in past. WON 07-200-203 Sa Sc PS A A SOO MODULES DESKTOP AND SERVER OS VULNERABILITIES a needed. Several excellent products are available and selecting the right one requires some research. An antivinis toal must be planned, installed, and configured correctly to ensure the best protectlon. An antivirus tool is almost useless II Xt isn't updated regularly. Ideally, an antivirus tool should automatically download and Install updates dally. If your examination of a system reveals that no antivirus tool is running, you should recommend installing one immediately. You must also stress keeping It up to date Jor the best pratection.
Enable Logging and Review Logs Regularly

Logging Is a crucial hinction for manttoring system security. It must be configured carefully to record only useful statistics, because averty verbase logging can easily overwhelm analysts. Review logs regularly for signs of intrusion or other problems on the network Bulld prevention and detection by considering what attackers might do II they compromised your network. ff you were an attacker and broke into a network you weren't [amiliar with, you would probably run some Windows administrative commands to understand more about the network. Commands like ipconfig /all, netstat -r,net view, and gpresult, especially when grouped together, could be seen as suspicious, given the proper context. H anon4echnical user suddenly makes administrative requests, it might be time to investigate further.

Scanning thousands of log entries Ls time consuming, and missing Important entries Is llkely. A log-monitoring tool is best for this task Several are available, depending on network needs and budget. Some of these tools even include
customizable automation that can give you an edge on an attacker by automating response (e.g, disabling a remote
systems network adapter) when the tools detect known malictaus activities.
Disable Unused Services and Filtering Ports
Disabling unneeded services and deleting unnecessary applilcations or scripts make sense because they otherwise
five inirnders a potential point of entry into a network. For example, if you have a Windaws Server 2016 system acting
as a file server, you don’t need DNS services running on It; dolng so leaves port 53 TCP/UDP open and vulnerable to
attack The idea is to apen onty what needs to be open and clase everything elke—also knawm as reducing the attack
surface. (The attack surface is the amount al code a computer system exposes to unauthenticated outsiders.) With
Jewer services exposed, an attacker Is leas Ilkely to find an unpatched vulnerability.
In addition, filtering out unnecessary parts can protect systems from attack Some ports frequently subject to
attack Include the following:
« FTP (20 and 21 TCP)
© TFTP (69 UDP}
© Telnet (23 TCP}
DNS (3 TCPAUDP)
« NTP (123 UDP)
© NetBIOS (135 TCP/UDP, 137 and 138 UDP, 139 TCP)
« SMB (445 TCP/UDP)
© Remote Desktop Protocal G389 TCP)
© SNMP (161 and 162 TCP/UDP)
Windows RPC programs (1925 to 1039 TCP/UDP)
The best way ta protect a network fram SMB attacks is 1a make sure perimeter routers and flrewalls filter out ports

137 t.139 and 445. Blocking ports 139 and 445 has the added benellt of protecting against external null session attacks. Windows Server 2003 doesn’t disable SMB on port 445 by deiault. [n Jact, if the computer ‘s a damaln controler, you need to pravide access to SMB. The server's job is to make sure the person attempting ta log an to the network is indeed authorized to access network resources. Because you usually want to share resources on a server, closing part
445 could create other prablems, such as users not being able to access shared folders and printers.

An attacker can gain entry thraygh many other ports. It isn't possible ta cloce all avenues of attack and still olfer the functionality users need, but with careful planning, an administrator can reduce the number of ways nto the network Far a complete list of ports and services, consult LANA’s Assigned Port Number page at wwwana org/ assignments/port-+uumbers.

The security fleld ls changing rapidly, and security professionals must keep up with new developments, threats,
and tools. Securing Windows systems can be challenging, bin you have access to many tools to pinpoint problems. LINUX OS VULNERABILITIES

Like any OS, Linus can be made more secure if users are aware of its vulnerabilities and keep current on new releases amd Iixes. It's assumed you have some experience working with a *nlx OS, so the basics of the Linux OS and file system
aren't covered In this module. Many Linux versions are available, with differences ranging Irom slight to major. For
example, Red Hat and Fedora Linux use the yum command to update and manage RPM (Red Hat Package Manager)

packages, and Ubuntu, Deblan, and Kall Linux use the apt -get command to update and manage DEB (Deblan) packages. Whatever Linux version you ise, you must understand the basics, such as run control and service configuration,
directory structure, file system, basic shel] commands and scripting, and package management. (II you're unfamillar
with these *nix basics, spend me reviewing them. One of the quickest ways security testers can make a poor lmpression on clients Is 10 show a lack of knowledge about the systems they're testing}

Atypical Linux distribution bas thousands of packages developed by many contributors around the world. With such diverse sources of code, It's Inevitable that some code will have flaws that are sometimes discovered only after they have been incorporated in the final product. Too many network administrators believe Windows is easter to attack amd view “nix OSs as inherently more secure. Security professionals must understand thal making these assumptions can be dangerous because all OSs have vulnerabilities. When conducting a security test on systems running Linux, you should follow the same niles you would far any OS.

Samba
Users expect to share resources over a netwark, regardless of the OS used, and companies have discovered that users
no longer tolerate proprietary systems that can’t coexist In a network To address the issue of Lnteroperabillty, a group
of programmers created Samba (wwwsamba org) in 1992 as an open-source implementation of CFS. With Samba,
“nix servers can share resources with Windows cllents, and Windows clients can access a “nlx resource without real-

zing that the resource is on a *nix computer. Samba has been ported to non-*nlx systems, too, including OpenVMS, NetWare, and AmigaOS. At the tlme of this writing, securiry professionals should have a basic knowledge of SMB and
Samba because many companies have a mixed environment of Windows and *nlx systems.
To access a ‘nix resource from a Windows computer, CIFS must be enabled on both systems. On networks that
require *nlx computers to access Windows resources, Samba 1s alten used. [t's not a backing tool; this product was

designed to enable *nix computers to “trick” Windows services Into believing that ‘nix resources are Windaws resources. A ‘nix client can Cannect to a Windows shared printer and vice versa when Samba 1s configured an the *nlx camputer. Most new versions of Linux include Samba as an optional package, so you don't need to download, install, and compile it.
