Embedded OSs are usually designed 1a be small and eificlent, so they don’t have same functions thal general-purpose OSs do, particularly Lf the specialized applications they run don't use these features. One type of specialized embedded OS is a real-time operating

system (RTOS), typically used In devices such as programmable thermostats, appliance controk, and even spacecraft. If you're piloting an F-35 fighter jet, youl certainly appreciate that the embedded RTOS In your aircraft ls designed
with an algorithm aimed ar multlrasking and responding predictably. RTOSs are also found In high-end Kitchen ovens, heart pacemakers, and ust about every new motor vehicle.
SECURITY BYTES

As you become acqualnted with devices that use embedded OSs, you need to think the way attackers do. What system could you attack that could affect hundreds of systems? Thousands of systems? Something as simple as an attack ona
company’s heating, ventilatbon, and air-conditioning (HVAC) system—or even a thermostal, for that matter—could do
serfous harm to the network Infrastructure.

With only a cursory survey af a typical corporate bullding, you can find many embedded systems, Including firewalls, switches, routers, web-tIltering appliances, network-attached storage (NAS) devices, networked power switches,
printers, scanners, copy machines, video projectors, uninterruptible power supply (UPS) consoles, Voice over IP (VoIP)

phones and voicemail systems, thermostats, HVAC systems, fire suppression systems, closed-clrcult TV systems, elevator management systems, video teleconferencing workstations and cansoles, and intercom systems. How many embedded systems can you identify in the bullding you're In right now?
SECURITY BYTES
Hacking a Model 3 Tesla was the final test in the 2019 Pwn20wn annual hacking event. The White hat hacking team of
Amat Cama and Richard Zhu {who go by the taam name of Ruaracetate) only needed 3 few minutes and 3 few lines of

code to hack the Tesla They exploited a weakness in the browser of the “infotainment” system, and soon thelr com mands were displayed on the Tesia’s center console screen. Flucracetate won most of the challenges they entered and left the competion with $375,000 In prize money and a brand new Tesla. The securtty flaw was reported to Tesla, and the car company issued a patch to eliminate the vulnerability.

Many dismiss the tapic al embedded device security to focus on mare papular security Issues. Most of the media emphasis ‘s on threats that peaple can understand and relate to, such as the latest network worm, the mast recent Windows attack, or the Colonial Pipeline cyber attack Hawever, embedded systems are In all networks and perform essential functions, such as routing network traific and blocking suspicious packets. Many believe that because devices use an embedded O85, no one wauld bother to attack them or Lake the time and effort to understand how they work. In fact, the oppasite is often the case. For example, three San Francisco hackers purchased several parking meters on eBay ta do just that—understand how the devices wark. They took apart the parking meters looking Jor security leatures
and ways to access the internal hardware {rom the outside, such as an external USB or serial port. They alsa tried ta

determine whether someone could jam a card ar gum, for example, inte the device ta disable it and Investigated what type oi smart card could be inserted, If any. Their goal was to canvince the City af San Francisco that a vulnerability study of the parking meter system was worthwhile.
Recently, security researchers were able to reverse-engineer the soltware ona popular firewall’s chipset; soitware

residing on a chip is commonly referred to as firmware. The researchers then Inserted modified software to contral the firewall’s behavior. Hackers who do this could modify a firewall so that they can copy network traffic passing thraugh an interlace and give an externa! IP address full access through the Mlrewall. They can also configure the brewall so thar these intrusiane would not be detected or generate a single log entry. WINDOWS AND OTHER EMBEDDED
OPERATING SYSTEMS

Recycling common code and reusing technologies are sound software engineering practices. Alter all, why should you pay a developer to write the same code repeatedly if you can just reuse it? Unfortunately, these practices introduce common points of jailure in many products. Many viruses, worms, Trojans, and other attack vectors take advantage of shared code, which increases the Impact a single vulmerablilty can have. You have already learned about vulnerablities in Windows and Linux Any vulnerability in these OSs might also exist in the embedded version. For example, the embedded versions of Windows 10 and Windows Server 2012 contain the same software and, with lew exceptions, operate the same way as their non-embedded counterpans. Windows XP had a very popular embedded release, which many products continue to use even after extended support expired in January of 2016.

Windows CE was a trimmed-down version of the Windows desktop OS and shouldn't be confused with Windows Embedded 8 or Windows 10 loT. Some Windows CE source code Is available to the public, and much of the rest of It is avallable to hardware vendors, partners, and developers, based on thelr licensing level Windows CE is rare now, but still worth knowing about. Windows Mobile, an old OS based on Windows CE, was designed for use In products

Some security professionals can remember when computer attacks typically caused damage equlvalent to graffiti on a bullding. Oltensive, yes, bal not damaging enough to concern most security professionals. However, the impact o! attacks has become more serlous, and embedded OSs are no exception. Websites such as www.explolt-db.com and www.packetstormsecurity.org have information on what hackers are doing with these vulnerabilities.

Many hackers today want more than just notorlety, however, they're criminals looking for ways to steal money. One way to profit Irom hacking Is to attack devices where cash Is stored and dispensed by a computer: ATMs. ATMs are vulnerable to attacks upon their sofware performed locally or remotely, or to physical attacks such as using card skimmers or even stealing the machines. Af the Black Hat conference in 2010, a security researcher, Barnaby Jack of Auniper Networks, famously demonstrated a vulnerability in a line of popular ATMs that made both local and remote attacks possible. He had two ATMs on stage that he hacked, causing them to spew out dozens ol crisp bills. He hacked

one machine remotely over a network, and he plugged a USB stick into a port on the other ATM to employ malware. More recently, in 2021, security researchers have sounded the alarm that near Meld communication readers (NFCs)

on ATMs are a vulnerability. NFC is a convenience feature that allows you to tap or wave your bank card on or near a reader device instead of Inserting it into the ATM. By using a smartphone with malicious software on it, the NFCs can ‘be exploited to crash the ATM, lock It up in a ransomware attack, hack It to extract credit card data, or jackpot the ATM to have It spew out money. This new threat ts why addressing the security af embedded systems early in the design phase—not treating It as an afterthought —ts exsential Embedded OSs Are Networked For reasons of efficiency and economy, connecting embedded systems to 4 network has advantages. Being able to manage systems and share services while keeping the amount of human resources and expertise to a minimum helps companies reduce costs. Gaining efficiency and reducing casts have a price, however: Any device added to a network infras tnocture increases the potential far security prablems. SECURITY BYTES Heart rate monitors and MRI machines are examples of systerns that run embedded Windows OSs. Often these syscems can't be patched because they're certified at a specific revision level, or the manufacturer never provided a patch method. This problem was apparent when the C onficker worm infected numerous medical systems around the world. Even in embedded systems that weren't cannecied directly to the internet, versions of Conficker spread through removable media. A simple daca qansfer with LSB drives, for example, might be risky. Embedded OSs Are in Networking Devices Networking devices, such as routers and switches, usually have soltware and hardware designed for the tasks of transmitting information across networks. Originally, general-purpase computers were used to perform routing and switching, but high-speed networks now use specialized hardware and embedded OSs. In the past, Cisco mainly used proprietary code in its embedded systems. By using more open-source code, however, Cisco can release new product

Jeatures more quickly. Cisco uses Linux kernels in its latest VoIP Cal] Manager appliances and Adaptive Security Appilance (ASA) Mrewall. Other embedded OSs Jor networking devices are modified *nlx OSs. For example, Juniper and
Extreme Networks 05s are based on UNIX.

You might wander why anyone would bather hacking routers or other networking devices, as they don’t contain corporate secrets and don’t have lots of storage space or processing capacity that could be stolen. The short answer is that when attackers compromise a hast, that's all they might get: a single hoet. When they compromise a router, they might be able ta contral every hast on the network Fram the router, attackers can map the entire network, modify

packets to and from hasts, redirect traific to and from other hosts or networks, attack other networks thal are accessible trom the compromised router, and make iree phone calls with VoIP, i It’s cantigured. In short, controlling a router
can give attackers complete access to network resources.

To compramise an entire network through a router, attackers fallow the usual methods of footprinting, scanning, and enumerating the target. Embedded OSs in rauters are often susceptible to many of the same altacks that plague general-purpose OSs, ranging Irom simple password guexsing to sophisticated buffer overflow attacks. A comman vulnerability of routers and other network devices with built-in web management interlaces Is the authentication bypass vulnerabibty. Attackers can take contral of a network device or gather sensitive information fram It by accessing the device with a specially crafted URL that bypasses the normal authentication mechanism. You might have found examples of authentication bypass vulnerabilities in Activity 9-2. Atter bypassing authentication, attackers can launch other network attacks by using the access they galned through compromising the router.

Tapping a traditional phone line used to require a lot of time, expensive technical equipment, and a warrant. Even then, all you caukd do was listen to a conversation Surprisingly, many peaple have the same security expectations of cell phones and smartphones.

running Google Android, Windows Mobile, and the Apple iPhone 05 G05). With the increasing amaunt of functionality available in smartphones, the line ls blurring between embedded and general-purpose OSs. These OSs, similar to

Rootkits
Roothits exist Jor Windows and *nix 04s, so embedded versions of these OSs are vulnerable to them, too. Rootiits

can modify parts of the OS or install themselves as kernel modules, drivers, libraries, and even applications. Roothitdetection tools and some antivirus software can detect rootkits and prevent them tram being Installed. However,

the problem hecomes more difflcnit fi the OS has already been compromised. Installing these toals on an Infected system doesn’t normally trigger alerts because rootkits can monitar the OS for antl-rootkit tools and neutralize
them. Rootkits that pose the biggest threat to any OS (embedded or general-purpose) are those that infect a device's
firmware. They're more dangerous because they tend to be extremely small, are loaded In low-level nonvolatile

storage that antl-rootkit tools can’t access readily, and can persist even alter the hard drive has been reformatted. Defenses against low-level rootkits include using Trusted Platform Module (TPM), a cryptagraphic flymware boatcheck processor installed on many recent computer systems. TPM ensures that the OS hasn't been subverted or
corrupted, such as with a firmware rootkit. TPM ls now the ISO standard ISO/IEC 11889. For more injormation on this standard, visit www.iso.org.

A computer might have several megabytes oj flash ROM on the motherboard and cantroller cards, such as the Ethernet controller. Firmware rootkits are hard to detect because the code for firmware often Lsn’t checked for possible corruption. Insider hacking is harder to detect with malicious code hidden in a system's Dash memory. Disgruntled employees, for example, could Install a BIOS-based rootkit in the Oach memory of their company computers before they leave the company. They could then use this BIOS rootkit, which woukd survive having the OS reinstalled, to gain access to the corporate network later.
SECURITY BYTES

For demonstration purposes, Microsoft and University of Michigan researchers developed a BIOS-tevel rootkit for PCs, called Subvirr, that can suntve hard disk replacement and OS reinstallation. SubVirt modifies the boot sequence and

loads Itself before the OS so that It can operate outside the OS and remain hidden from many roothil-cetecdon toals. By exploiting hardware virtualization technology from CPU manufacurers, SubVirt can load the original OS as a virtual
machine and then intercept the OS's calls to hardware.

What li the system you're using is compromised before it's even purchased? Criminals in Europe have tampered with credit card machines while they're stil in the supply chain The compromised devices continue ta

function Like normal credit card readers with one notable exception: They copy customers’ credit card Informatlon and transmit It to criminals via a cell phone network. The only way to get rid af these types of infections Is

to flash (rewrlte} the BIOS with a known clean copy, wipe the hard drive, and reload the 05 from clean installatlon media. These tasks can be hugely expensive in both time and money, but at least a method jor removing the
malware is avallable.

A popular laptop theft-recavery service, LoJack for Laptops, has some design-level vulnerabilivies that rootkits can exploit. Researchers irom Care Security Technologies reconiigured LoJack with a custom BIOS rootkit that takes advantage of LoJack’s vulnerabilities. Because the infection resides in the computer's BIOS, It persists even after the OS is relnstalled ar the hard drive is replaced. Of mare concern to security professionals ls that the LoJack BIOS agent is stored ina part oi the BIOS that isn’t overwritten when you Dash It. The LaJack BIOS agent periodically “calls home” to
acentral monitoring authority for inetructions in case alaptap ls reported stolen The cal}-home mechanism allows the

monitoring authority to instruct the LoJack BIOS agent to wipe all information as a security measure or to track the stolen system's location. Because so many laptops have this agent installed and It can’t be removed, it's an attractive target to attackers.

An application can be tested using two main techniques: Static Application Security Testing (SAST) and Dynamic

Application Security Testing (DAST). SAST Is analyzing an application's source code tor vulnerabilities and Is, therefore, only possible when the source code of an application is available. SAST is a reHable way to enomerate most appllcatlon vulnerabilitles that result from coding errors. SAST Is also known as “white box testing.” DAST is analyzing a

yonning application for vulnerabibties. h can also be used alongside SAST to prioritize SAST findings. [f source code is Not available to testers, DAST Is all they can perform. DAST is also known as “black box testing.” Another application
testing technique called Interactive Application Security Testing (IAST) combines elements of both SAST and DAST

and uses an agent inside the application to perform Its analysis in real-time af any polnt in the development process. 1AST is also known as “gray box testing.” This section tocuses largely on the execution of DAST. Several security4esting checklists and guides walk a security tester through dynamic testing of each component of

a web application, ensuring full coverage. The following sections are based on the “OWASP Web Application Penetration Testing Guide” (www.owasp.org/index php/Web_Application_Penetration_Testing), which has been developed
and vetted by experts from around the world. Information Gathering and Architecture Mapping

Authorization Testing Authorization Is the act of checking a user's privileges to allow or deny access to a page, Held, resource, or actlon In an application Application developers commonly use hidden elds In tables and obscured URLs to enforce thelr access control instead of checking users’ privileges before processing a request. Il low-privilege users know what URLs to request, they can escalate thelr privileges ln a poorty designed application. Insecure direct object references, described earlier, are discovered during authorization testing. Authorization testing can reveal major areas of concern and Is an important part of any application test. Input Validation Input validation Is the act of filtering, rejecting, or sanitizing a user's untrusted input before the application processes it. Input valldatlon problems can lead to data disclosure, alteratlon, and destruction. When applications accept untrusted Input, an attacker can often craft malicious requests that cause the application to perform an unexpected action. This is where the injection vulnerability arises. An attacker can cause a server to run code, overfill a buffer, perform database queries, reflect malicious content back to users, and many other destructive actions. One example of input validation gone wrong is SQL injection. SECURITY BYTES When studenss apply for graduate school, walting for an accepeance letter can be painfil, but a hacker offered them a way of getting an answer quickly. The hacker gained access to intemal acimissions records for Harvard, Stanford, MIT, and other top business schools by exploiting vwuinerabilides discovered In a web application called Apply'Yourself, The hacker then posted hacking hints on Business Week’ online forum. To read more, vist weww.thecrimson comvartice/2005/3/3! hacker-ips-off-b-schoo-appiicants-tipped/. Applicants, regardless of thelr hacidng backgraund, could now find out whether they had been accepted. Harvard Business School identified 119 applicants wha hacked the system and stared that It would reject thelr admissions because of the ethics violation. Some people thought the problem was the lack of security on the ApplyYourself web server, which alowed an attacker to simply modify the web server's displayed URL. The applicants who were caught used their logon names and changed only the URL when connected to the web server. They didn't aempt to hide thelr qacks or guess passwords. Was what they did unethical? This question might seem difilouk to answer, but Harvard had no problem doing just that. Although this incident occurred years ago, It's sdll a good lesson In poor website security and the repercussions of hacking. Error Handling Aweb application can be configured or written to handle errors in a varlety af ways. For example, when an application needs to undergo traubleshoating, developers can enable debugging, which pravides rich logging intarmation helplul 1a diagnose lesves. Sometimes, alter traubleshoating, the debugging mode might be leit on, which provides a valuable source of Information Jor attackers. Developers should minimize the amount of Information shared with users when an application encaunters an error. Optimally, na information or only a generic message shauld be displayed to users in these error cases. Cryptography Testing Cryptography can be intimidating for Junior security testers. in cryptography are due to simple problems: bad random number generators; a known weak method oi encryption;
an encryption algorithm with known flaws that allow It to be cracked; an application that doesn't actually enforce the
use of secure channels; or a self-signed certificate Instead of a purchased certificate. To dlecaver Naws ln the actual

For example, befare conducting a wire transfer, a user must first satisfy the requirement of having af least that amount of money in the transferring account. If the user doesn’t have adequate funds, the transfer should be halted. Business logic testing Invalves using creative ways to bypass these types of checks. Can you samehow trick the application Inte thinking you have $1,000,000 in your account when you only have $100? What implications might this have for the bank that authorizes a wire transaction Jor $1,000,000 fram an account with $100? These types of Naws can expose a company
to legal, financial, and reputational lasves and should be a point oi focus during application testing.

and an Ethernet cable (the wire serving as the connection medium). As complex as wireless networks might seem, they
too have anly a few basic components: « Wireless network interface cards (WNICs), which transmit and recelve wireless signals, and access points.
(APs), which are the bridges between wired and wireless networks

The fallowing sections explain how an AP and a WNIC function in a wireless network
Access Points
An access point (AP) is a radio transceiver that connects to a network via an Ethernet cable and links a wireless LAN
(WLAN) to a wired network. Some wireless networks do not connect to a wired network, such as a peer-to-peer netwarks,

bot this topology isn’t covered because security testers are seldom contracted to secure a peer-to-peer wireless network Moet companies conducting security tests use 4 WLAN thal connects to the company’s wired network topology. RF channels are configured ln an AP. Figure 1-1 shows APs detected on channel 11] by Vistumbler (an AP-scanning
program covered In “Understanding Wardriving™ later in this module). Hackers look for APs as they drive around with

an antenna and a laptop computer scanning for access. Channels are explained In more detall later ln “The 802.11 Standard.” For now, think of a channel as a range or frequency that dala travels over, Just like a channel on the radio.

An AP enables users to connect to a LAN with wireless technology. The AP can be configured to transmit and
receive only within a defined area or square footage, depending on the technology. II you're 20 miles away from an AP,
you're probably out of range.
Service Set Identifiers
A service set identifier (SSID) is the name used to Identify a WLAN, much the same way a VLAN JD Is used to Identify

network VLANs. An SSID is configured on the AP as a unique, 1: to 32-character, case-sensitive alphanumeric name. To access the WLAN the AP connects to, wireless-enabled computers must be configured with the same SSID as the AP. The SSID name, or “code,” is attached to each packet to Kdentify 11 as belonging to that wireless network The AP
usually beacons (broadcasts) the SSID several times a second so thal users who have WWINICs can see a display of all
WLANs within range of the AP’s signal The SSID is broadcast in cleartext (unencrypted test), which can be a securiry
issue. Anyone who detects the SSID of the AP can attempt to connect to it, Including hackers. To better secure your AP,
you can disable SSID broadcasts so that only people who know (or guess) the SSID can connect to it On Figure 11:2, the
Windows 10 wireless connection manager shows SSID advertised by APs within range of the wireless computer. Same
WNWICs come with builtin wireless connection software that looks different from the Windows utility.
= 4 . i] 3 a Figure 11-2 SsiDs advertised toa Windows computer

Many vendors have SSIDs set to a default value. For example, Clsco APs previously used the default SSID “tsunami.” Typical default SSDs are single words such as Wireless, Netgear, Linksys, Admin, and Defauh, though default SSIDs can change often. As a security professional, you must research constantly and gather Information to keep abreast of changes in this industry. If an AP Is configured to provide its SSID after authentication, wireless hackers can attempt to guess the SSID by using a wellunown default SSID. Make sure yoor cllent isn’t using a default SSID.
Sometimes, a default SSID can tell an attacker that the target AP is old or out of date. [f a wireless AP Is using the
defauh SSID, {1 might also be using other defaults such as the default username and password for the administrative
Jogin. Whackers wanting to access an AP find a default SSID, they will try the defanh administrative login credentials first.

Wireless NICs

To send information over any medium, a computing device must follow the rules for the medium It's traversing, so the correct soltware and drivers for the NIC must be Installed. For example, data traveling over a copper wire must follow rules for how Ethernet signals are sent over that medium. For wireless technology to work, each node or computer must have a WNIC, which converts the radio waves It recelves Into digital signals the computer understands.

There are many WNICs on the market, but be carelul deciding which one to purchase It you're considering using specillc tools for detecting APs and decrypting WEP keys or using antennas that can cover a large distance. For instance, AirCrack-ng, a program for cracking WEP encryption on a WLAN, requires using a specific chipset on a WNIC, so only certain brands of WNICs can be used.

MODULE 11 HACKING WIRELESS NETWORKS a UNDERSTANDING WIRELESS NETWORK STANDARDS

A standard Is a set of rules formulated by an organization All Industries have standards, and a WLAN is no exception. Just as the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) has standards specifying maximum cable length
in an Ethernet network, it sets rules to follow for wireless networks.
Working groups (WGs) of the IEEE are formed to develop new standards. After a WG has reached consensus on a

proposal Jor a standard, the Sponsor Executlve Committee must approve the proposal Finally, alter the proposal ts recommended by the Standards Review Committee and approved by the IEEE Standards Board, you have a new standard.
IEEE Project 802 was developed to create LAN and WAN standards. (The first meeting was held ln February 1980,
so the project was given the number 802, with °80" representing the year and “2” representing the month.) WG names
are also assigned numbers, such as 1] for the Wireless LAN group, and letters to denote approved projects, such as
802.11a or 802.11b. ln this module, you learn about the 802 standards pertaining to wireless networks.
The 802.11 Standard

The Grst wireless technology standard, 862.11, defined specifications for wireless connectivity as 1 Mbpe and 2 Mbps in a LAN. This standard applied to the Physical layer of the OS] model, which deals with wireless connectivity issues
of fixed, portable, and moving stations In a local area, and the Media Access Control (MAC) sublayer of the Data Link
layer. Often, multiple transmitters are nearby, so radlo signals can mlx and have the potential to Interlere with each
other (as signal collislon). For this reason, carrier sense multiple access/ collision avoldance (CSMA/CA) is used instead
of the CSMA/CD method (collision detection, used in Ethernet).

Many definitions of terms are Included in the more than 500 pages of the 802.11 standard One important distincion is that wireless LANs dan’t have an address associated with a physical location, as wired LANs do. In 802.11,
an addressable unit is called a station (STA). A station Is defined as a message destination and might not be a fixed
Jocation. Another distinction is made between mobile stations and portable stations. A mobile station is one that
accesses the LAN while moving. a portable station is one that can move from locatlan to location bur Is used only
while In a ilxed location.
Basic Architecture of 802.11
302.11 uses a basic service set (BSS) as its bullding block A BSS Is the callection of devices (AP and statlons or Just
Stations) that make up a WLAN. A basic service area (BSA) is the coverage area an AP provides. A WLAN running in

what's called infrastructure mode always has one or more APs. An independent WLAN without an AP Is called an ad-hoc network, independent stations connect In a decentralized lashion. As long as a station ts within Its BSA, It can communicate with other stations ln the BSS. You have probably experienced losing cell phone connectlviry when you're oot of range of your service area. Similarly, you can lose network connectivity if you aren't ln the WLAN’s coverage

area To connect two BSSs, 802.11 requires a distribution system (D§) as an intermediate layer Basically, BSS 1 connects to the DS, which In turn connects to BSS 2. However, how does a station called STA | in BSS 1] connect 10 STA 2

in BSS 2? 802.11 defines an AP as a station providing access to the D5. Data moves between a BSS and the OS through the AP. This process sounds complicated, but Figure 11-6 should clear up any confusion.
The IEEE specifications also define the operating Irequency range of 802.11. In the Unlted States, the range is
24 to 2.4835 GHz. Think of the frequency as a superhighway im the sky where data travels, and thls superhighway
encompasses many highways (Jrequency bands}. Each frequency band contains channels, which break up the band

Into smaller frequency ranges. For example, channe] 1 of a irequency band ranging bom 2.4 GHz to 2.4835 GHz might use the 2.40] GHz frequency, and channel 2 of this frequency band might use 2 406 GHz. The 802.11 standard defines
channels In the 2.4 to 2.462 GHz range. If channels overlap, interference could occur.
Sound travels through the air in waves, and like ocean waves, the length of a sound wave 1s measured from
the peak of one wave to the next. A sound wave’s amplitude (height) and frequency (rate at which a sound wave
repeats) determine its volume and pitch. Soriers wailing for the next set of waves to ride can accurately determine
Jrequency (the time It takes a set of waves to repeat). Completing a repeating pattern of sound waves Is called a

cycle. For surfers, a cycle can be minutes. Sound waves, however, repeal at a much faster frequency. For example, a tuning Jork vibrates at 440 Hz, or cycles per second. That's 440 waves per second—too iast for a surfer. Ditlerent technologies use diilerent frequencies, referred to as bands, to transmit sound. Table 11-1 Ilsts frequency bands.

Modulation delines how data ts placed on a carrier signal. For example, spread spectrum modulation means
data 1s spread across a large-trequency bandwidth Instead af traveling acrass just one frequency band. In
ather words, a group af radio frequencies is selected, and the data is “spread” across this group. Spread
Spectrum, the most widely used WLAN technology, uses the following methods:
o Frequencyhopping spread spectrum (FHSS): Data hops to ather frequencies to avold interference that might
occur over a Irequency band. Hopping from one Jrequency to another occurs at split-second intervals and
makes It difficult far an intruder ar attacker to jam the communication channel
o Direct sequence spread spectrum (DSSS): Unilke FHSS, DSSS spreads data packets simultaneously over multiple

bequencies instead oi hopping to other frequencies. Sub-bits are added to a packet as It travels across the frequency band and are used for recovery, in much the same way RAIDS uses pariry bits ta rebulld a hard disk that crashes. Sub-bits are called “chips,” and every bit of the original message is represented by multiple bits, called the chipping cade.
o Orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM): The bandwidth is divided into a serles of frequencies
called tones, which allows a higher throughput (data transfer rate) than FHSS and DSSS da.
o Onhogonal frequency division multiplexing Access (OFDMA): OFDMA is the multiuser extension of single

user OFDM. ODFMA has a throughput three times higher than OFDM for short packets of data or multiple endpoints. OFDMA combines transmissions and sends frames to multiple endpoints simultaneously. ht is more eilicient with lower latency transmission. This makes OFDMA ideal for [aT devices, video, anline gaming, and antamation applications.

UNDERSTANDING AUTHENTICATION

The problem of unauthorized users accessing resources on a network is a major concern for security professionals. An organization that Introduces wireless technology to the mlx increases the potential for security problems. The 3802.1X standard, discussed in the following section, addresses the issue of authentication. Some routers, by default, do nat require authentication, which cauld leave a corporate network at risk.
The 802.1X Standard

Because there must be a method to ensure that others with wireless NICs can’t access resources on your wireless network, the 802.1X standard defines the process of authenticating and authorizing users on a network This standard is especially useful for WLAN security when physical access control is more difficult to enforce than on wired LANs. To understand
how authentication takes plare on a wireless network, review basic authentication concepts In the following sections. Point-to-Point Pratocol
Many ISPs use Paint4o-Paint Protocol (PPP) to connect dialup or DSL users. PPP handles authentication by requiring a user
ta enter a valid username and password. PPP verilbes that users attempting to use the link are indeed who they say they are. Extensible Authentication Protocol
Extensible Authentication Protocal (EAP), an enhancement to PPP, was designed to allow a company to select its ainhem>

cation method. For example, a company can use certificates ar Kerberos authentication to authenticate a user comecting to an AP. A certificate Ls a record that authenticates network entities, such as a server or cilent 2 contains X.509 information
thal identfies the owner, the certification authorlry (CA), and the owner's public key You can examine an X 509 certificate
by going to www.amaron.ca This website redirects you to the secure (HTTPS) URL, where you click the padlock Icon at
the left of the address bar in Chrome, and then click Certificate to see the certificate information shown in Figure 11-7.
The follawing EAP methods can be used to improve security an a wireless network:
« Extensible Authentication Protocol- Transport Layer Security (EAP-TLS)}—This method requires. assigning the

client and server a digital certificate signed by a CA that both parties trust This CA can be a commercial company that charges a fee, or a server coniigured by a network administrator to iasue certificates. In this way, both the server and cllent authenticate mutually. In addittan to servers requiring that clients prove they are wha they say, cilents also want servers to verify their kientity.

© Protected EAP—Protected EAP (PEAP) uses TLS to ainhenticate the server to the cient but not the client to the server. With PEAP. only the server Is required to have a digital certificate. (See RFC-2246 lor more inlormation on TLS.}

WEP encryption ls easily cracked due
to a flaw in its RC4 encryption algorithm. The encryption key used by the algorithm is a 24-bit Initiaization vector (IV)
in combination with a default key. The 24-bit IV is too short and easy to break. Some argue that WEP ls still betrer than
no secuntty at all, and when it's combined with the security of a virtual private network (VPN), they claim that WEP
works well for bome users or small businesses. Still, many saw a need for a better way ta protect WLANs. Wi-Fi Protected Access
‘WI-Fi Protected Access (WPA, WPAZ, and WPA3), specified in the 802.115 standard, bs the replacement Jor WEP, whicb
is knawn to have cryptographic weaknesses. WPA improves encryption by using Temporal Key Integrity Protocol
(TKIP). TKIP bas four enhancements that address encryption vulnerabilities In WEP:
© Message Integrity Check (MIC}—MIC, pronounced M--C and also called Michael, is a cryptographic message

integrity code. Its main purpose is to prevent Jorgeries, which are packets that attackers create to look like Jegitimate packets. For example, an MIC uses a secret authentication key, which only the sender and receiver

know, and creates a tag (a message Integrity code) generated from the key and message sent to the receiver. The sender sends the message and tag to the receiver, wha must enter the key, tag, and message in a program that veriiles whether the tag created with the three input flelds ls equal to the tag the program shoukt
have created. You don’t need to memarize this process but should understand that MIC corrects a known vulnerabillty in WEP.

© Extended initialization Vector {1V) with sequencing rufes—This enhancement was developed ta prevent replays. in a replay, an attacker records or captures a packet, saves lt, and retranemits the message later To prevent
a replay from occurring, a sequence number is applied to the WEP IV feld. If a packet is received with an [V
equal to or less than the sequence number received earlier, the packet ls dlecarded.

« Perpachet key mixing—This enhancement helps defeat weak key attacks that occurred in WEP. MAC addresses are used to create an intermediate key, which prevents the same key trom being used by all inks.

« Rekeying mechanism—This enhancement provides fresh keys to help prevent attacks that relied on reusing old keys. That Is, if the same key is used repeatedly, someone running a program ta decipher the key could likely do so after collecting a large number of packets. The same key being used repeatedly was a big problem in WEP.
WPA also added an authenticatlan mechanism using 802.1X and EAP, which weren't avallable in WEP.
Since the release of WPA, weaknesses have been found in TKIP. which called for a more advanced WPA2. WPA2
replaced WPA In the official Wi-F} standard. The main difference between WPA and WPA2 Is the requirement in WPAZ
to use AES encryption Instead of TKIP.

WPA3 was released in January 2018. WPA3 officlally replaces WPA2 and provides improved security features. Far encryption, WPA3 uses AES-256 and SHA-384 in WPA3-Enterprise mode, and still mandates the use of CCMP-128
(AES-128 in CCM Mode) as the minimum encryption algorithm in WPA3-Personal mode. WPA3 replaces pre-shared key
(PSK) exchange with Simultaneous Authentication of Equals (SAE) exchange, which results in a more secure initial
key exchange

Wi-Fi Protected Setup (WPS)
Wi-Fi Protected Setup (WPS) Is a wireless authentication standard created to allow users to add devices easily and
securely to a wireless network.

WPS makes this process éasler by eliminating the need for a user to enter a passphrase. Rather, the user simply presses a buttan an the router and the WPS-enabled device pairs with the router. Chances are, # you have a modem router at home, it is capable of WPS.

WPS might sound Ike a great solution, but a major security Daw was discovered in late 2011. This flaw allows an attacker to galn access to a network remotely without knowing the WPA2 password. UNDERSTANDING WARDRIVING It's prababtly no secret that hackers use wardriving—driving around with Inexpensive hardware and software that

enables them to detect access points that haven't been secured. Surprisingly, some APs have no passwords or security measures, so wardriving can be quite rewarding for backers. As of this writing, wardriving Isn't Illegal; using the
resources of networks discovered with wardriving 's, of course, a different story. Wardriving has now been expanded

10 include warilying, which involves drones with an antenna and the same software used in wardriving The testers used Kismet, covered later in this sectian, which identifies APs that attempt to “cloak” or hide their SSIDs.
How It Works

To conduct wardriving, an attacker or a security tester simply drives around with a Wi-Fi capable smartphone ar Japtop and software that scans the area for SSIDs. Not all WNICs are comparible with scanning software, so review the software requirements before purchasing the hantware. Antenna prices vary, depending on thelr quality and the range they can cover. Some are as small as a cell phone's antenna, and some are as large as a bazookas. The larger ones can
sometimes return results on networks miles away from the attacker. The smaller ones might require being in close
proximity to the AP.

Most scanning software detects the company’s SSID, the type of security enabled, and the signal strength, Lndicating how close the AP Is to the attacker. Because attacks agalnst WEP are simple and attacks agalnst WPA are possible, any 802.11 connection not using WPA2 or WPA3 should be considered Inadequately secured. An ethical hacker in Houston, previously employed by the county's Technology Department, was accused of breaking Into a Texas court’s wireless network, While he was conducting scans as part of his Job, he noticed a vulnerability in the court’s wireless network and was concerned. He demonstrated to a county official and a local reporter how easily he could gain access to the wireless network with just a laptop computer and a WNIC. He was later charged with two counts of unauthorized access of a protected computer system and unauthorized access of a computer system used in justice administration. After a three-day trial and 15 minutes of jury delfberation, he was acquitted. If he had been found gullty of all charges, he would have faced 10 years In prison and a $500,000 fine.

UNDERSTANDING WIRELESS HACKING

Hacking a wireless network Is similar to hacking a wired LAN. Many of the port-scanning and enumeration tools yau've Jearned about can be applied to wireless networks. The follawing sections describe additional tools that attackers use, which you can use to conduct security tests.
Tools of the Trade
A wireless hacker usually has a laptop computer, a WNIC, an antenna, sniffers (Tcpdump or Wireshark, for example},

However, some companies still use 802.11b with WEP enabled, and some even Jeave their network completely unsecured.

Vatsyayana almost 2000 years ago, recommends that men and women learn and practice the art of cryptography, which it defines as “the art of understanding writing In cipher and the writing of works in a peculiar way.”

As long as peaple attempt to create encryption algorithms to protect data, athers will endeavor to break them. The study of breaking encryption algorithms is called cryptanalysis. h’s tanght In universities and by government agencies, bot hackers also find the challenge oi breaking an encryption algorithm intriguing and continue to lorce develapers 04 encryption algorithms to push the envelope in finding harder-to-break algorithms. When a new encryption algorithm is developed, cryptanalysis is used to ensure that breaking the code is impossible or would take so much time and so many resources that the attempt wouki be Lmpractical. In other words, lf breaking an encryption algorithm requires the processing power of a $500 million supercomputer and 500 years, the algorithm can be considered secure enough for practical purposes.
When cryptanalysis is feasible with a reasonable amaunt af computing power, however, an attack on the algorithm is deemed “practical,” and the algorithm is considered weak.
The War Machines

The most Iamous encryption device was the Enigma machine, developed by Arthur Scherblus and used by the Germans during Worki War IL Most books on cryptography discuss this device. How did it work? The operator typed a letter 1a be encrypted, and the machine displayed the substitution character for the letter. The operator then wrate dawn this substitutlon character and tumed a rotor ar switch. He or she then entered the next letter and again wrate dawn the substitution character Enlgma displayed. When the message was completely encrypted, it was transmitted over the airwaves. Of course, the message could be decrypted only by the Enigma machine al the other end, which knew in what positions to shilt the rotors. The code was broken first by a group of Pallsh cryptographers, and then by the British and Americans. The machine British and American cryptologists used for breaking the code, developed by British mathematiclan Alan Turing, was called the Bombe.

During World War ll, the Japanese developed anather natable war machine, called the Purple Machine, that used techniques discovered by Herbert 0. Yardley. A team led by William Frederick Friedman, a US. Army cryptanalyst known as the Father af US. Cryptanalysis, broke the code. The FBI had employed Mr. Friedman and his wile to assist in decrypting radio messages sent by bootleggers and smugglers during the 1930s. These encryption codes proved ta be more difficult and complex than those used during wartime.

The main purpose of cryptography Is ta hide Information Jram others, and there are methods al hiding data thar don’t use encryption. One is steganography, a way of hiding data in plain Wew in pictures, graphics, or tex. For example, a picture of a man standing in front of the White Hause might have a hidden message embedded that gives a spy information about troop movements. [n 1623, Sir Francis Bacan used a form of steganography by hiding Wits of Information in variations of the typeface used in books.

Two types of symmetric algorithms are used currently: stream ciphers and block cipbers. Stream ciphers such as A5/1, A5/2, and RC4 operate on plaintext one bit af atime. Messages are treated as a stream af bits, and the stream cipher performs mathematical functions on each bit, which makes these algorithms great candidates for hardware or
pevel] encr yptlon devices. Block ciphers such as DES, 3DES, AES, and RCS operate on Mocks of bits. These blocks

are used as input to mathematical functlons that perform substitution and transposition of the bits. Sometimes, when a block cipher separates input into blocks, lt must add padding to fill a given block This padding leaves the cipher susceptible to attack Publicized attacks include CRIME, BEAST, and Lucky 7, which are all types of Padding Oracle attacks. Data Encryption Standard
Adiscussion of symmetric algorithms must include Data Encryption Standard (DES). The National Instiune of Standards
and Technology (NIST} wanted a means of protecting sensitive but unclassified data, so in the early 1970s, it iwited
vendors to submit data encryption algarithms. The best algorithm would become the standard encryption method

A new standard was needed because DES was no langer the salutian. Triple Data Encryption Standard (3DES) served

Advanced Encryption Standard Eventually, NIST decided that 3DES was a stop-gap measure for a weak algorithm and a new standard was In order:

Advanced Encryption Standard (AES). In 1997, NIST put aut another request to the public for a new encryption standard, asking for a symmetric block cipher capable of supporting 128-, 192-, and 256-bit keys. Of the five finalists, NIST
chose Rijndael, developed by Joan Daemen and Vincent Rijmen, because of Its Improvements in security, efficiency,
performance, and Dexibility. The other Jour Mnalists were MARS, RC6, Serpent, and Twofish (See https://carc.nist gov
for more details.) AES-256, part of the NSA’s Suite B set of cryptographic algorithms, is one of the only commercial
algorithms valldated as strong enough to pratect classified informatlan. International Data Encryption Algorithm
International Data Encryption Algorithm (IDEA) is a block cipher that operates on 64-bit blocks of plaintext. It uses a
12-bit key and Ls used in PGP encryptian software (covered later ln “Asymmetric Algorithms”). DEA was developed by

Xuejia Lai and James Massey ta work more elficlently In computers used at home and In businesses. It’s iree lor noncomMerdial use, but a llcense must be purchased for commercial use. The final patent far the IDEA block cipher expired in 2012. Blowfish Blowfish is another block cipher that operates on 64-bit blocks of plaintext. However, the key length is variable, irom
32 bits up to 448 bits. It was developed as a public-domain algorithm by Bruce Schneier, a leading cryptalogist and the
author of Applied Cryptography: Protocols, Algorithms, and Source Code in C Second Edition (Wiley, 1996, ISBN 0471117099},

which is highly recommended for those who want to leam more about the algorithm and view its C source code. RC4 RC4, the most widely used stream cipher, ls used in WEP wireless encryption. [t's because oj the way RC4 is implemented in WEP that finding the key with air-cracking programs, for example, Is so easy. RC4 is considered dificult ta break, but It should be avoided for most applications. The algorithm was created by Ranald L. Rivest in 1987 for RSA
Security (www.rsa.cam)

RCS RCS ls a block cipher thar can operate on different block sizes: 32, 64, or 128 bits. The key size can reach 2048 bits. The algorithm was created by Ronald L_ Rivest in 1994 for RSA Security. Asymmetric Algorithms Instead of the single key used in symmetric algorithms, asymmetric algorithms use two mathematically related keys,
#0 data encrypted with ane key can be decrypted only with the other key. Another name for asymmetric algorithms is
public key cryptography; these terms are often used interchangeably. A public key is openly avallable: in many cases,
poblic keys can be downloaded tram websites far the public to use. A private key is the secret key nawn anly by the
key awner and should never be shared. Even If peaple know the public key used to encrypt a message, they can’ figure
out the key owner's private key. With asymmetric cryptosystems, a public key being intercepted In transmisslan Isn't
a concem. In addition, asymmetric algorithms are more scalable than symmetric algorithms because ane public key
can be used by thousands of users; however, these algorithms require more pracessor resources, so they're slower.

Before examining some widely used asymmetric algorithms, take a look af a simple example of public key cryptography. There ave dilferent ways to encrypt a message with asymmetric algorithms, depending on whether the goal is to
provide authentication and nonrepudiation. Authentication verifies that the sender or receiver (or both) is who he or
she claims to be. Nonrepudiation ensures that the sender and receiver can't deny sending or receiving the message. These functions aren't supported in symmetric algorithms.

U User A encrypts a message with her private key and sends the message to User B, User B can decrypt the message with User A's public key. A user's peivate and public keys are mathematically related, meaning a public key can
decrypt only a message that has been encrypted with the corresponding private key.
U canfidentiabty ls a majar concern Jor User A, she encrypts the message with the recipient's public key. That way,
anly the recipient can decrypt the message with his private key. li User A wants to assure User B that she is Indeed the
person sending the message (authenticatian), she can encrypt the message with her private key. Alter all, she's the
anly person who possesses her private key.

RSA was published in 1978 by three MIT professors: Ronald L. Rivest, Adi Shamir, and Leonard M. Adleman. [1's the

of this approach and suggested the professors cease and desist. When questioned about the legality ol its request, hawever, NSA didn’t respond, and the algorithm was published. You can flnd more information about RSA and Its relationship with the NSA at https://en. wikipedia orgAviki/RSA_Security.
Many web browsers using the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocal nse the RSA algorithm, which is based on

the difficulty of factoring large numbers. To generate a key, RSA uses a onesay functton—a mathematical formula that’s easy 10 Compute in one direction but difficult ar nearly impoesible ta compute in the apposlte direction For example, multiplying two large prime numbers to determine thelr product ls easy, but when you're given only the product, determining what numbers were used in the calculation is difficult. This algorithm was developed ln 1976 by Whitbeld Ditile and Martin Hellman, originators of the public and private key

relationship. i a key ls intercepted during transmisslan, the network bs vulnerable to attack, so key management is an

munication without the fear of interception.
Elliptic Curve Cryptography
Efliptic curve cryptagraphy (ECC), developed in 1985, is used Jor encryption as well as digital signatures and key

Digital Signatures
Asymmenic algorithms have a useful feature that enables a public key to decrypt a message encrypted with a private
key, or vice versa. A public key can only decrypt a message that was encrypted with the corresponding private key.

Digital Signature Standard
In 1991, NIST established the Digital Signature Standard (DSS) to ensure that digital signatures could be verified The
Jederal government specified using RSA and Digital Signature Algorithm (OSA) lor all digital signatures and using a
hashing algorithm to ensure the message's Integrity (verlfying that the message hasn't been tampered with). NGT
requires using Secure Hash Algorithm (SHA), covered later In “Hashing Algorithms.” Basically, a digital signature can be
created with only a user's private key, and the user's signature can be verified by anyone using this user's public key.

Several] hashing algorithms are in use today; Table 12:2 summarizes some of the most common. A hashing algorithm is
4 function that takes a variable-length string or message and produces a fixed-length hash value, also called a message
digest, used to verily integrity of the data or message. [n a sense, it's like a fingerprint of a message For example, li the

message “How are you?” is changed later to “Wha are you?” the hash value also changes so that the recipient knows the original message changed during transmission. Two different messages producing the same hash value results in a colllstan. Therefare, a gaod hashing algarithm Js one that’s resistant to calllsions.

Many legacy systems rely on Message Digest 5 (MDS) and Secure Hash Algorithm 1 (SHA-1) hawever, modem systems are rapidly upgrading to SHA-2 and SHA-3. By the end of 2016, major web browsers no longer supported SHA-|. With

a reasonable amount of computing power, MDS hash collisions can be found in a few days. Attacks on SHA-1, the 160-bir version of SHA, are now considered more practical, and researchers have been publishing attack methods. Since 2015, experts have recommended not using SHA-1. Federal

agencies have been instructed by NIST to remove SHA-1 from future applications and replace It with either SHA-2Z or SHA-3. As you can see, security professionals must be vigilant In keeping aware of changes. Banks, e-commerce websites, credit

to enter a Joreign country, the Customs agents viewing the passport don't necessarily trust the passport hokers. They do, however, trust the passport agency thal issued the passports, so the U.S. citizens are allowed to enter the country.

poblic key you used is Indeed Ye-Jun’s public key because you trust the CA thar issued it.

Man-in-the-Middle Attack

Ina man-in-the-middle attack, attackers place themselves between the victim computer and anather host computer. They can then intercept messages sent from the victim to the bost and pretend to be the bost computer. This type of
attack follows this process:
Gloria sends her public key to Bruce, and you, the attacker, intercept the key and send Bryce your public
key. Bruce thinks he just recetved Gloria’s public key, bot he received yours.
Bruce sends Gloria his public key. You intercept this key, tao, and send Gloria your public key.
Gloria sends a message to Bruce, encrypted Ln what she thinks ts Bruce’s public key, but because she's
using yours, you can decrypt the message with your private key.
You then can reencrypt the message with Bruce's public key and send Lt to Broce.
Bruce answers Gloria by encrypting his message with what he thinks is Gloria’s public key. You Intercept
the message, decrypt It with your private key, encrypt lt with Gloria's real public key, and then send Lt to
Gloria.
You might have to read these steps a few times ta understand how thls type ol attack works. Using Index cards with
the names of participants written on them night help you get a clearer picture of what's taking place; this technique
is used in Activiry 12-4.

U a password uses common words found in a dictionary, mast password-cracking programs can use a dictionary file to speed up the process. Brute force is a common method for cracking a password. One way to speed up a brute-torce cracking effort is by using a rainbow table. A passward-cracking program can use this lookup lable 0 passward hash values instead of trying random computations on a password hash’s keyspace. For rainbow tables 1o be effective, hawever, they need ta store a Jot of hash values. Also, ralnbow tables for passwords that contain more than 10 characters can quickly fill hundreds o/ terabytes of storage due to the exponential nature of available permutations relative ta the length of a password.
Asalt, in cryptagraphic terms, is the use of random data alongside plaintext as an input to a bashing function so

thar the omtpat is unique. Salts make pre-calculated rainbow tables worthless because the resulting hashes are comPletely different due to the random data included in the hashing routine. Salts should always be used when storing passwords. In some oi the large breaches oi websites In recent history, unsalted passwords exposed users’ passwards and led to account compromise and additional compromise lor users who had the same paseword across multiple sites.
Agraphics processing unit (GPU} greatly exceeds a CPU's capability ta process mathematical calculatlans. A typ

cal GPU has hundreds of cores, whereas a typical CPU has faur or eight cores. Each of these cores can process one mathematical calculation per cycle. At the thme oi this writing, parallel processing across hundreds oi cores gives GPUs three to five times greater thraughput for hash cracking when compared with CPUs. Programs like Hashcar can be set 1a leverage the GPU rather than the CPU.

Using Routers to Reduce Network Attacks Routers, which operate at the Network layer of the TCP/IP pratocol stack, are hardware devices used ta send packets 1a diferent network segments. Their main purposes are to reduce broadcast trailc passing over a network and choose the best path for moving packets. For example. if Router A In Spain wants to send a packet to Router B In [owa, the packet can probably take several paths. Routers use routing protocols in this best-path decision-making process that
function in the following ways:
© Linksfate rowting profocol—a router using a link-state routing protocol sends link-state advertisements to
other routers; these advertisements identify the network topology and any changes or paths discovered

recently on the network Far example, li a new router or path becomes avallable tor a packet, this Information Ls sent to all other routers participating In the network. This method Is elfictent because only new informa: tlon is sent over the network An example of a Iink-stale routing protocol is Open Shortest Path First (OSPF). © Distance-vector routing protocol—t a router Is using a distance-vector routing protocol, It passes Its routing
table (containing all possible paths it has discovered) to neighboring rauters on the network These neighbor

routers then forward the routing table to heir nelghbors. Two examples of distance-vector routing protocols are Routing Internet Protocol version 2 (RIPv2} and Enhanced Intertor Gateway Routing Protocol (EIGRP).
© Path-wecior routing protocol—aA path-vector routing protocol uses dynamically updated paths or routing tables
to transmit packets from one autonomous network to another. ft tent used on LANs because It’s used mainly
by ISPs and Large organizations with multiple Intemet connections to ather GPs and organizations. The main
path-vector routing protocol is Border Gateway Pratoco] (BGP), a routing pratocol that an ISP uses to transmit

packets to thelr destinations on the Internet. SECURITY BYTES BGP does have some security vulnerabiltes. For example, attackers might hijack IP space belonging to another ISP by Injecting a malidous BGP routing advertisement for a network prefix they don’t own. 200 doud-based web providers and content delivery networks was redirected through Rostelcom, Russia's state-owned telecommunications prodder. Cver 8000 Intemet traffic routes were affected for approximately two hours, sowing or
halting trafftc coming from or destined to Amazon, Google, Facebook, and many other sites. For more information about
this BGP hijacking Incident, vish www.darkreading com/edge-ardicles/101 -why-bgp-hijacking-justaworrt-die. = Lamale, 2020, ISBN 1119677610).

PROTECTING WITH FIREWALLS

Firewalls can be hantware devices with embedded 05s. or saltware installed on general-purpose computer systems. Firewalls serve two main purpases: controlling access to traliic entering an internal network and controling traffic Jeaving an internal network Firewalls can be installed on a network to protect a company’s internal network [rom dangers existing on the Internet. On large enterprise networks, Mrewalls can also protect internal network segments, such as those cantalning anly application servers, trom otber internal network segments—lor example, those containing employee workstations. For instance, a typical enterprise firewall approach is restricting the remote desktop port TCP 3389, used tor remote administration of application servers, ta only the system administrator network segment and allowing only ports 80 and 443 for web traffic on the network segment containing employee workstations. In this example, clearly, typical employees don’t need to administer application servers, so this approach reflects a least: privileges philasaphy.
Hardware and software firewalls have advantages and disadvantages. However, instead of making recommendations,
this module focuses on how firewalls Mt into a security strategy. Briefly, the disadvantage of hardware firewalls ls that

you're locked into the firewall's hardware, such as the number of interfaces it includes. With a software firewall, you can add NICs easily to the serwer running the saltware. A disadvantage oi software flrewalls ts that you might have ta worry about configuration problems, such as memory requirements, hard disk space requirements, number of CPUs supported, and £0 on. Software brewalk also rely on the O5 on which theyre nunning. For example, Windows Flrewall ls available on Windows 10 and Windaws Server 2016. Anather example is iptables, Included with Kali Linux Hardware flrewalls, such as
Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (covered later ln this module), are usually faster and can handle a larger throughput
than software firewalls can.

As you have seen, a router can also be used to Ger traffic entering or leaving Its Interface. Fulrering can be set up with access lists that restrict tralfic based on the source IP address, destination [P address, protocol, and port. However, a brewall is spectitcally designed as a network protection system and has mare security features than a router. The most basic security leature of a frrewall is Network Address Translation (NAT). One Jab oi a security professional
is to hide the Internal] network trom outsiders. With NAT, internal private IP addresses are mapped to public external
IP addresses, hiding the internal infrastructure fom unauthorized personnel For example, a user with a private IP

address of 10.1.1.15 has ber address mapped to an external IP address af 193.145.85.200. The outside world sees only the external IP address and doesn’t know the internal (P addresses the company uses.

Aher hackers know 4 computer or server's IP address, they scan that system for open or vulnerable ports. Hiding IP addresses Jrom hackers can help prevent these scans irom being successiul. To accommodate the many addresses
thar need to be mapped, many organizations use Port Address Translation (PAT), which is derived from NAT. It allows
mapping thousands of internal IP addresses to one external [P address.

Access Lists As discussed in the section an routers, access lists are used to filter traific based on source IP address, destination IP address, and ports or services. Application Layer Inspection An application-aware firewall inspects network traific at a higher level in the OSI madel than a traditional stateful packet inspection firewall] does. SP] ensures that a packet's source, destination, and port are Inspected before forwarding the packet, but a flrewall performing appllc ation layer inspection also makes sure that the network traffic's application pratocal s the type allawed by a nule. For example, many Trojans get past Mrewalls by launching a reverse shell that originates fom the compromised system and connects to a remote system the hacker controls. This reverse shell is the hacker's secure command-and-control tunnel, and It’s usually disguised by using a commonly allowed outbound port, such as port 443. IDSs can also be categorized by how they react when they detect suspicious behavior. Systems that don’t take any action to stop or prevent an activity are called passive systems. They do, of course, send an alert and log the activity, moch ike a security guard at a shopping mall witnessing an armed robbery. Security Operations Center
The (Ss, IPSs, and honeypots (discussed in the next section) that help keep a network secure require administrative

expertise to set up, run, and maintain. in smaller companies, when a security event happens, usually administrators have to clean up the mess and then make a report to management or the legal department or work with law entorcement For large organizations that have sensitlve or critica] data, normal administrative expertise isn't enough to follow up and do damage assessment, risk remediation, and legal consultation. For these types of organizations, you might need to recommend creating a Security Operations Center (SOC).

Large organizations need a permanent team whose members are responsible solely for security-response functions. Another function of a SOC Is monltoring for artifacts left behind by attackers, which indicate that a system or
network has been compromised; these are often called indicators of compromise. Security information and Event

Management {SIEM) tools can help the teams identliy attacks and indicators of compromise by collecting, aggregalting, and correlating log and alert data from routers, flrewalls, IDS/IPS, end point logs, web-ilrering devices, honeypots,

and other security tools. Bringing the alerts together fom these devices gives a security-monitoring analyst context to make better-informed decisions. Popular SIEM commercial products Include AP ArcSight, RSA EnViston, and [BM QRadar. Open-source SIEM products include AkenVauht OSSIM and LOGalyze.
USING HONEYPOTS

Ahoneypot ls a computer placed on the network perimeter that contains Information or data intended to lure and then trap hackers. The main goal Ls to distract hackers Irom altacking legitimate network resources. A security professional configures the computer to have vulnerabilitles so thar hackers spend time trying to exploit these vulnerabilitles. Another goal of a honeypot is to have hackers connect to the “phony” computer long enough to be detected, as In movJes when the FB] wants a criminal to stay on the phone long enough to trace his or ber location. [n addition, a honeypot
¢an serve as an excellent data collector and early warning system to help characterize new attacks and threats; this
information makes it easier lor security professionals to defend networks against them.

SECURITY BYTES Bug bounties are finandal rewards paid by organizadons to individuals or groups who discover and report Baws in that organization's sofmaare or computer systems. The process. used to discover the flaws is essentially penetration testing, In October 2021, Polygon, a blockchain technology company, paid $2 millon in bug bounty rewards for a “double spend* vulnerablitty chat could have wreaked havoc across its network. The flaw was discovered by an ethical hacker named Gerhard Wagner. The flaw enabled an attacker to double the amount of cyptocurrency they Intended to withdraw up to 233 times.

This flaw could have allowed a malicious actor to deposi only $4,500 and then immediatety withdraw $1 millon. An attacker with $3.8 millon could explol the flaw to acquire up to $850 million. Apparently, ethical hacking pays. It also appears that crime pays, bul ethical hacking ts righteous, and crime Is not.
